DOC.HEAD: Veteran Diplomat Dead at Age 90
DOC.TEXT: Joseph C. Satterthwaite, a retired diplomat whose posts included director general of the Foreign Service and assistant secretary of state, is dead of pneumonia at age 90. He died Nov. 19 in Washington. He began his diplomatic career in 1924 as a clerk at the U.S. consulate in Stuttgart, Germany. Satterthwaite was ambassador to what was then Ceylon, Burma and South Africa. He retired in 1965.

DOC.HEAD: Golden State Praying For Rain, But Bracing for Fifth Drought Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The first few storms of the rainy season have arrived in California, bringing a little moisture and a torrent of hope that the state will dodge a disastrous fifth year of drought. The four-year drought, the worst in 60 years in some areas, already has cost the nation's most populous state hundreds of millions of dollars in losses, hitting farmers the hardest. Worst-case scenarios for another dry year call for business shutdowns, heavy crop damage, wildlife losses and devastating brush fires. Lawmakers also envision one of the fiercest water wars in state history between cities and farmers. The state's top weather forecasters have been running numbers through their computers all summer, and the best they can come up with is that nobody knows what the winter will bring. ``The only thing left is to appeal to the higher being to bless us with rain,'' said Ralph Klages, a nursery owner in the Los Angeles suburb of Monterey Park. ``It's frustrating and it's scary, because we have a lot to lose.'' The rainy season, which began Nov. 1, has gotten off to an unsettling start. A series of mid-November storms people hoped would dump lots of rain and snow petered out, leaving precipitation levels in most areas well below seasonal averages. Even in the absence of storm clouds, many Californians see a silver lining. Water experts say the drought might accelerate water management plans to avoid the day fast-growing California wants more water than it can get. But many of the solutions - from additional water storage to desalination plants - are too far in the future to help most Californians, who are bracing for the worst if the inter of 1991 comes up dry. In the Southern California mountains, ski lift operators who have had to make do with small snow packs in the past worry that shrinking water supplies could even keep them from making fake snow. ``We haven't had a good snow winter in a few years,'' said Monica Bandows with Bear Mountain Ski Resort near Big Bear Lake. ``But now there is a chance that if the lake falls below a certain level, we'll no longer be able to pull water out for man-made snow.'' Ron Klievoneit, who operates French Gulch Marina on Lake Isabella in Kern County, said business has declined 25 percent since the lake level dropped. Some store owners have gone out of business, he said. ``A lot of them have not had enough of a cushion and have gone defunct,'' said Klievoneit. ``We've owned this place for nearly 10 years. We've been successful at it. And I will just have to find ways to be successful for years to come.'' Farmers also could have to find a way to get through another dry year. Agriculture suffered an estimated $480 million in drought-related losses this year, according to the state Department of Water Resources. In California, farmers get their water from several sources, including their own wells and state and federal water projects. Unless the 1991 water year is wetter than last season, farmers could have their government water supplies cut by one-half to two-thirds, federal and state officials say. ``Tree crop farmers are having particular problems,'' said Mike Henry, spokesman for the California Farm Bureau Federation in Sacramento. ``Last year, they started seeing trees beginning to stress. The roots are searching for water and they're not finding any. The tree itself starts to change its metabolism to survive and not produce fruit.'' Urban residents also face water cutbacks. State deliveries could drop as much as 13 percent and federal deliveries could decline 25 percent to 50 percent, officials said. Some cities already have imposed rationing, most notably Santa Barbara on the hard-hit Central Coast, where some residents paint their dead lawns green and wash their cars with dry rags. That area has no access to government water supplies and relies solely on local sources. Los Angeles, the state's largest city, had voluntary water conservation this summer. After early success, the water use inched back up near the end of summer, and mandatory rationing next summer could be imposed. A cut in water supplies to industrial users would be devastating. A 24 percent reduction could cost Los Angeles industry $25 billion and 350,000 jobs, according to estimates by William S. Wade, a consultant to the Metropolitan Water District, a Southern California water broker. Electronics manufacturers, for instance, rely heavily on water, and even a small cutback in their already tight supply could force them to reduce production. With water in short supply, the competition could turn ugly. Some lawmakers say Southern Californians could lobby state and federal water authorities to pressure central California farmers into giving up more of their supplies. ``It could get very cannibalistic for awhile,'' said Assemblyman Jim Costa, D-Fresno. Humans aren't the only ones who suffer in a drought. In the Angeles National Forest, the drought is hurting wildlife by drying up water sources and making the plants less nutritious. Mule deer are having fewer fawns, black bears are coming down from the hills to the campgrounds looking for food and water, and smaller, less mobile animals such as wood rats and ground squirrels are dying, said forest biologist Bill Brown. Animals also have gone beyond the campgounds and into neighborhoods. In San Diego County, people have reported foxes eating cat food, raccoons slurping pool water and bobcats lurking around jogging trails. The dry brush also increases the possibility of wildfire. The state had one of its worst fires in history this summer when hundreds of homes were destroyed in a Santa Barbara area fire. Water officials say they have no idea how much precipitation the state can expect this winter. But even a normal winter won't solve all the state's problems, they say. Experts say the state needs a wetter-than-normal winter, and even a second normal winter. ``If we get a normal water year, we can make all the state water deliveries,'' said state Water Resources engineer Bob Fingado. ``However, that would leave our reservoirs at the same level, and that's low.'' And even after the state gets out of the current drought, California's problems aren't over. The population explosion is straining the basic water system. Officials now are drafting long-term water plans, including better conservation, improving the coordination between water agencies and finding ways to reuse water. California could become the leader in building plants that make sea water drinkable. Although a very expensive source of fresh water, desalination facilities are under construction or in the planning stages in Los Angeles, Santa Barbara and Marin counties. ``This drought should really serve to be a wake-up call for all of us,'' said Byron Buck, director of water resources planning for San Diego County.

DOC.HEAD: Records Show Wilson Weakened By Disease During League of Nations Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: President Woodrow Wilson's behavior was affected by decreased blood flow to the brain during his oft-criticized and ultimately futile campaign to have the United States join the League of Nations, a historian says. Records that were never made public show that Wilson was disabled by illness during the critical period in U.S. history after World War I, said Princeton University history Professor Arthur Link, editor of a series of volumes of Wilson's papers. ``It is one of the great tragedies of the 20th century,'' Link said in a recent interview. ``The man who was most responsible for building support for the idea of a League of Nations was struck down just as his leadership was most needed. And he was struck down by events over which he had no control.'' The 64th volume in the series, to be published in February, will reveal for the first time detailed medical records kept by Dr. Cary T. Grayson, Wilson's personal physician. Grayson's sons allowed Link to review the 70-year-old papers in May. Link said the records, with analysis by medical experts, explain Wilson's poor performance in the months leading up to his devastating stroke in October 1919. Wilson, a Democrat, was president from 1913 to 1921. He died in 1924. He won the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize for his peacemaking efforts involving the League of Nations after World War I. However, he failed to win U.S. support for the League, which fell apart before World War II. Link said U.S. entry into the League of Nations could have altered history. ``In a world with the United States playing a responsible, active role, the possibilities of preventing the rise of Hitler were limitless,'' Link said. Wilson failed to get the Senate to ratify U.S. membership in the league because of what Link said was an uncharacteristic unwillingness to compromise. The Senate wanted guarantees that the United States would not be subordinate to the votes of other nations in case of war. ``In his normal, healthy state, Wilson would have found compromise with the large group of moderate Republicans,'' said Link. Instead, Wilson was robbed of ``his ability at leadership, of his normal shrewdness and deftness, of his marvelous management skills,'' said Link. ``He would lose his train of thought, and get confused. He would contradict himself, and eventually, blow his cool.'' Against medical advice, Wilson, then 63, took his message directly to the people with a speaking tour of Western states in September 1919. The decision to go over the Senate's head angered the very lawmakers Wilson needed to court. ``The decision ... was not only irrational but in the circumstances was bound to be futile,'' Link writes in the forthcoming book. Dr. James F. Toole, director of the Stroke Center of the Bowman Gray School of Medicine in Winston-Salem, N.C., and Dr. Bert E. Park, a Springfield, Mo. neurosurgeon, analyzed the medical records for Link's book. Toole wrote that the records indicate Wilson suffered from a disease of the carotid arteries in the neck, which hindered blood flow to the brain, and hypertension, which worsened his condition. Park wrote that Wilson likely continued to suffer episodes of internal bleeding following a 1906 stroke. This could cause injury leading ``in time to recognizable behavioral disturbances that typified Wilson from late 1919 onward,'' Park wrote. Link said the records should lay to rest the theories that Wilson's problems were psychological. ``His failure in leadership instead derived from the ravages of disease,'' Link said. ``History has judged Wilson as if he were a well man during this period.''

DOC.HEAD: Professor Says Wilson's Wife Didn't Run Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Woodrow Wilson
DOC.TEXT: The popular belief that President Woodrow Wilson's wife ran the government after her husband's devastating stroke in 1919 is ``pure nonsense,'' according to a historian at Princeton University. History Professor Arthur Link, editor of a series of volumes of Wilson's papers, said the 64th volume, to be published in February, will prove that Mrs. Wilson served as a liaison but was not effectively an ``acting president'' in Wilson's final year in office. The volume quotes medical records and journals kept by Dr. Cary T. Grayson, Wilson's personal physician and confidant. Grayson's sons allowed Link to review the 70-year-old records in May. ``It is a popular belief, but it has gotten more into the realm of legend than scholarship,'' said Link. Edith Wilson did make two crucial decisions following Wilson's stroke, Link said. She covered up the extent of Wilson's illness and thwarted suggestions that he resign. Link said Mrs. Wilson long denied being an acting president and once told him she was ``never interested in politics.'' Grayson's journals show that Mrs. Wilson served as a liaison between Wilson and his advisers, but that the government was run by his department heads, Link said. Wilson was president from 1913 to 1921. He suffered the stroke in October 1919, never fully recovered, and died in 1924.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leaders Question Bush's Commitment to Fight Discrimination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights advocates are questioning President Bush's commitment to fighting discrimination despite the administration's aggressive prosecution of some ground-breaking voting rights and housing bias cases. They cite Bush's veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which would have made it easier for victims of discrimination to sue their employers. ``That fallout is going to take some time to clear,'' said Drew Days, who ran the civil rights division under President Carter. Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, had a harsher assessment. ``Once again, we have an administration defying the bipartisan consensus that exists on civil rights,'' he said. Still, civil rights leaders acknowledge there are bright spots in the Bush administration's record. Bush actively courted black voters during the 1988 campaign, invited Coretta Scott King to the Republican National Convention, and spoke about healing racial divisions. He is credited with appointing more blacks to political jobs than his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh tried to re-establish ties with civil rights leaders that were left badly frayed by conservative William Bradford Reynolds, who ran the Justice Department's civil rights division under President Reagan. He also played a major role in ensuring passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, which bars discrimination against people with mental and physical handicaps. The Justice Department also has made enforcement a priority, adding lawyers to bring cases under a new statute that expands the government's authority to counter housing discrimination. It has forced municipalities to drop restrictions against group homes for mentally retarded people. The agency recently won a jury verdict against a landlord for refusing to rent apartments to a drug program to house recovering addicts. The Justice Department filed suit to force the all-male Virginia Military Institute to admit women cadets. It moved to overturn Georgia's election system, which it says discriminates against black office seekers. ``When I came here it was with the understanding with the attorney general that I would be responsible for the vigorous and the complete enforcement of the civil rights laws,'' said John Dunne, who was named assistant attorney general for civil rights after the Senate Judiciary Committee blocked Bush's first nominee, William Lucas. ``No matter what the subject area, we have been extremely aggressive,'' Dunne said. Civil rights advocates want more. ``They are going to have to make a record across the board, it's not going to be sufficient to carve out enclaves where they are vigorous and leaving others untouched and uncared for,'' Days said. Neas says he finds ``very few substantive differences'' in Justice Department policy from the Reagan administration when it was headed by Attorney General Edwin Meese III. And on many major issues of dispute involving the 1990 civil rights bill, ``the Thornburgh Justice Department was much worse than the Meese Justice Department,'' Neas said. ``Thornburgh strikes you as being the planet Jupiter, a failed star. You would have anticipated much more from him,'' said Barbara Arnwine, an attorney for the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. The bill Bush vetoed would have restored an evolving legal standard dating back 18 years for discrimination cases involving employer policies that have a ``disparate impact'' on women and minorities. Bush said it would spawn hiring quotas by encouraging businesses to employ and promote minorities simply to avoid costly court suits. Civil rights lawyers accuse the president of using divisive rhetoric to mischaracterize the bill, which contained language stating that no provision was designed to promote quotas. ``It's dividing people when this was the president who was going to try to heal those divisions,'' said William Taylor, a Washington civil rights lawyer. Both Taylor and Arnwine charge that the Bush administration wants to eliminate ``disparate impact'' cases to protect business from the costs of discrimination suits. ``They believe that if somebody didn't intend to discriminate, they shouldn't be held accountable,'' Arnwine said. Dunne rejected this view, providing figures showing that the since Bush took office the civil rights division has brought nine disparate-impact suits against state and local governments. But civil rights activists contend that the department wastes valuable time and resources pursuing reverse discrimination cases, such as a recent lawsuit accusing the Maryland Lottery Commission of discriminating against white males by setting aside 12 positions for women and minorities. ``We don't apologize for bringing reverse discrimination cases,'' said Roger Clegg, one of Dunne's deputies who also served in the Reagan administration. ``The law requires us to enforce the law in an even-handed fashion.'' The bitterness that lingers following Bush's veto is fueled by charges that the administration failed to bargain in good faith with the bill's supporters. ``The sense of many in the civil rights community is that the administration strung people along, giving them the sense there really was room for negotiations and compromise when there really wasn't,'' Days said. ``The administration is going to have to work very hard to re-establish its good faith,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ideological Opponents Become Trade Partners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Less than two years ago, South Africa and Eastern Europe shunned each other as ideological villains. Today, the South Africans have diplomatic or trade arrangements with Poland, Romania and Hungary, and are expanding contacts with the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia. Dramatic political and social changes on both sides have made them eager to renew relations after decades of enmity over communism and apartheid. ``We were at the other end of the world, both geographically and ideologically,'' Foreign Minister R.F. Botha said on a trip to Czechoslovakia. ``After the changes in both parts of the world, there is nothing which divides our governments.'' Botha and Czechoslovak officials announced plans to establish low-level diplomatic ties after a 27-year hiatus. In August, Trade Minister Kent Durr became the first South African Cabinet member to visit the Soviet Union in 34 years. Ideology drove the two sides apart in the 1950s and 1960s. Economics is bringing them together in the 1990s. The South African government invoked the threat of a communist takeover for decades as justification for suppressing the black opposition. This year, President F.W. de Klerk legalized all opposition groups, released African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela from prison after 27 years and promised to end the apartheid system of racial segregation. One of de Klerk's objectives was to end international sanctions, which have isolated South Africa economically and politically. East European countries supported the sanctions and backed the ANC and its ally, the South African Communist Party. Then, in 1989, came the upheaval that dismembered the Soviet bloc and swept Communist parties from power in Moscow's former satellites. Those nations are struggling to rebuild their crumbling economies and have found a willing trade partner in South Africa. Although they still oppose apartheid, East European countries have switched from being the main financial support of the ANC to dealing with the white government it sought to destroy. Delegations from Eastern Europe visit South Africa regularly. Permananent representatives have been exchanged and trade agreements signed. Thousands of Eastern European and Soviet citizens have applied to South African embassies in Western Europe for permission to immigrate. ``I am pleased that the dynamics of late 20th century political transformation are bringing our two nations once again closer together,'' Durr said in opening the first Polish trade fair in South Africa. Poland dropped trade restrictions against South Africa on March 9, the day after Durr completed a visit. In late October, the governments signed an agreement to establish reciprocal offices of interest. Polish government and trade officials traveled to South Africa for the two-week trade fair, which featured nearly 50 manufacturers of products ranging from heavy machinery through textiles to vodka. Organizers said contracts worth $60 million were signed. The visitors emphasized their continued opposition to apartheid, but it was clear that relations had been made more palatable by Poland's economic problems and South Africa's reforms. ``Poland is heavily in debt'' and is beginning to make its economic relations with the rest of the world ``much more active,'' said Andrzej Zawislak, an economist and member of Parliament. Zawislak said some Western countries had urged Poland not to establish ties with South Africa, but did not identify them. Romania and South Africa signed an agreement last month for a joint trade committee that would meet annually, and specific trade contracts are expected. South Africa has opened a permanent office in Hungary to represent its interests and Hungary plans to reciprocate. Hungarian officials said their country still opposes apartheid, but wants the office because about 20,000 people of Hungarian descent live in South Africa. African nations also are warming to South Africa's reforms. Only Malawi has full diplomatic relations, but several have trade missions in Pretoria and de Klerk has visited seven African countries since taking office in August 1989. His government says it trades with every African country, mostly in secret. Mandela has sought funds for the ANC in Africa, Western Europe, the United States and Asia, but has yet to visit Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union, which provided most of the movement's military aid while he was imprisoned.

DOC.HEAD: Killer, Rocky and Spaz Make Female Football a Smash Hit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA1 Nov. 25
DOC.TEXT: Players wore names like Killer, Rocky and Spaz on their jerseys. Cheerleaders in combat boots shouted through orange pylons and waved pink paper pompons. Spectators stacked their rifles and gas masks to do the wave. This was Sunday afternoon football with a twist: the players were women. A team of Marines called the Wrecking Crew toppled the Desert Foxes, from U.S. Navy Fleet Hospital No. 5, 20-13 in front of adoring troops who roared, howled, barked and booed the referees, naturally. ``It's a change of pace. Everyone was able to blow off a little steam,'' said Marine Cpl. Carrie Cripps, 21, of Fort Smith, Ark. A middle linebacker, she is also known as Rocky. The Desert Foxes were weary and dirty but far from discouraged because they stayed within a touchdown of the women Marines. The Foxes had practiced only eight times before, all on an asphalt parking lot. ``We're all nurses. We didn't know the first thing about football. I thought we were going to get trounced,'' said Lt. Com. Raelene Hoogendorn of McDonald, Pa. Also known as Killer, she works in casualty receiving. This wasn't the NFL, but it was the closest thing available in Saudi Arabia. The game is called flag football, a version of touch, although there were more than a few tackles and there was some crisp blocking. Players traded high-five handshakes and spiked the ball on touchdown receptions. The game was played on a sand field that the Marines call the Scud Bowl, although this one was billed as the Turkey Bowl as part of Thanksgiving weekend. Every play kicked up a cloud of dust, and the women panted and puffed in the 90-degree heat. Armed Forces Radio did a play-by-play. Several hundred Marines watched from the sidelines, some sitting on their sleeping cots or under tent flaps. They munched on popcorn, pretzels and crackers. There was no beer, only Kool-Aid and soda pop, although the two sidelines chanted the Miller Lite exchange of ``Less Filling'' and ``Tastes Great'' before the game. All in all, it was a pleasant afternoon for service members who have been training in this parched land for nearly four months. ``Nobody's in their tents. It breaks the monotony,'' said Gunnery Sgt. Eugene Bradley, 33, of Dallas. ``It's something to do on a Sunday. Tomorrow we go back to work, back to the old grind. Boy, look at those linebackers!'' Sgt. Chris Dempsey, 25, of Cleveland, led other Marines in cheers. ``When the women play, people come out of the woodwork to watch,'' Dempsey said. ``There ain't no place to go. You can't go to town. There's no alchohol. We're pretty well isolated.'' The game would also be unheard of elsewhere in Saudi Arabia, where men and women may not mingle in public. Even photographs of women playing sports are almost unheard of. ``This is a crowd pleaser. You can't get no better than this,'' said Lance Cpl. Stephen Banks, 22, of Pittsburgh. On the other side of the field, Cpl. Greg Williams, 22, of Billings, Mont., screamed himself hoarse while waving his pom-poms. ``There's not much to do out here,'' said Williams. Capt. Richard Mayo, commander of Fleet No. 5 Hospital, wished his carges well before they took the field in their white T-shirts adorned with red crosses, a contrast to the Marines' drab brown shirts. ``This is one way of channeling their frustrations,'' Mayo said from the bench. As befits a multinational force, a number of British soldiers watched the game. ``I love American football. Love the atmosphere,'' said Cpl. Mick Gibbons, 28. ``You don't have the rowdies we have in British soccer.'' About 350,000 troops are in Saudi Arabia as part of a multinational force deployed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. They face about 460,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: The Temple Mount Six Weeks Later: Some Answers, More Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic Nov. 25.
DOC.TEXT: Six weeks after the smoke and sting of tear gas drifted away from the Wailing Wall and Dome of the Rock, anger and recrimination remain from the bloody riot at the sites sacred to Jews and Moslems. Israel still is trying to block a U.N. investigation of the deaths of at least 17 Arabs killed by police gunfire. Hatred has grown on both sides. The Oct. 8 riots brought revenge stabbings by Arabs and renewed fervor in the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising. Then came stonings by Jews and growing calls that Arab workers be barred from Israel. Passage of time and a half dozen investigations by Israelis and Arabs show that first accounts of the Temple Mount tragedy from Israeli officials and from Palestinians drew more on anger than accuracy. The findings conflict with Israeli assertions that the Arabs deliberately provoked trouble by raining thousands of stones on tens of thousands of worshipers at the Wailing Wall. Even the government's own inquiry concluded that the melee began with stones thrown at police on Temple Mount, not at Jews near the wall, which also is called the Western Wall because it forms the western base of Temple Mount. The commission, headed by former secret service chief Zvi Zamir, listed nine Jewish civilians hurt by stones, a toll inconsistent with first reports of a barrage rained down on worshipers. On the Palestinian side, there is no evidence for initial charges that an Israeli helicopter fired tear gas and guns at Moslems on Temple Mount. Accusations of a ``planned provocation'' by Palestinians or a ``premeditated, well-planned operation'' by Israel do not mesh with what is now known. Chaos, not planning, characterized the riot. Zamir's commission notes that police lost communication with each other, some did not hear orders and there was ``unsupervised'' gunfire by some officers. Many Moslem witnesses said later they did not understand why the rioting started. Israeli officials first accused Palestinians of carrying rocks to Temple Mount to start a riot. The Zamir report did not repeat that charge, and all accounts now say the stones were lying around at a construction project. Betselem, an Israeli human rights group, said ``information given the public ... was for the most part imprecise, raising the suspicion that attempts were made to hide facts ... and evade responsibilty.'' There probably never will be complete agreement on what happened. The Zamir commission did not have subpoena powers and said it interviewed few Palestinian witnesses. Palestinian accounts discounted the police version. Israelis and Palestinians also saw the confrontation from their own side of the wall - and their own point of view. The riot came on a day of high emotion. Up to 30,000 Jews had gathered at the Wailing Wall for the Sukkot festival. Jews revere the wall as the last remnant of the ancient Jewish temple. As many as 5,000 Moslems had gathered in the walled compound above the wall, the area known in Arabic as the Haram es-Sharif, or ``Noble Enclosure.'' It is Islam's third-holiest site and contains the Dome of the Rock and Al Aqsa Mosque. The Moslems were incensed by rumors that a Jewish extremist group, the Temple Mount Faithful, planned a march on the holy sanctuary. The group, founded after the capture of Arab east Jerusalem from Jordan, wants to rebuild the ancient Jewish temple on the Mount. Authorities had barred them from Temple Mount, but allowed a rally nearby, fueling Moslem fears of an intrusion. The riots began about 10:45 a.m., when the priestly Sukkot benediction was over and the Jewish worshipers were dispersing from the plaza in front of the Wailing Wall. According to the Betselem group of liberal lawyers and professors, violence started when Palestinian youths threw stones at police in a courtyard near the Dome of the Rock. Those in the plaza cannot see what is happening up on Temple Mount, and people on the plateau around the Dome of the Rock cannot see directly down on the plaza because of the wall. Police responded with tear gas. Betselem noted that thousands of Moslems could not see the stone throwing and grew angry at the sudden use of tear gas. Indeed, two Palestinian reports found no evidence of stone throwing before the tear gassing. The Zamir report mentions neither stonings nor tear gas at this point. Its account of the rioting begins - and others call this the next step - with an angry mob charging police on the Temple Mount. Some rioters attacked a small police station manned by two men. Others threw rocks and metal objects at police near one wall - the interior of the Jews' Wailing Wall, which is at least 20 feet high inside Temple Mount. Early reports said the rioting started after cries of ``Kill the Jews!'' came from mosque loudspeakers. Palestinians deny there was such a cry and the Zamir report is ambiguous on the point. According to the 50-page English-language version of the report, the cry was heard from ``a loudspeaker.'' Elsewhere, however, it says the cry was among shouts ``heard from the direction'' of the mosques. Police answered the rocks with tear gas and rubber bullets. At least one officer fired live ammunition into the air. police were overwhelmed and fled the walled compound. Palestinians say live ammunition was then fired at rioters from a police station overlooking the area. Betselem says gunfire was ``probably'' used. The Zamir report says ``there was no intentional firing of live ammunition'' at this point. The remaining Jewish worshipers were evacuated from the plaza at the Wailing Wall. This appears to account for the few injuries. While some of the first rocks cleared the wall around Temple Mount and fell on the plaza below, both the Zamir and Betselem reports describe the heavy barrage of stones coming after police fled and the Jewish worshipers left the Wailing Wall. A little after 11 a.m., police charged back into the compound. Palestinians say they came in shooting. The Zamir report says they opened fire only after the mob refused to retreat. The commission's report says use of live ammunition was justified by danger to the policemen's lives, their fear for the safety of Jewish worshipers and for the lives of the two officers still in the station on the mount. In fact, the two policemen had taken refuge with mosque guards and were safe, but the police did not know that because of a communications breakdown. The Zamir commission said it was doubtful all the gunfire was needed, noting that using live ammunition had been justified ``only for policemen who ... were in mortal danger.'' Betselem said police fired indiscriminately, using bursts of automatic weapons fire and shooting at ambulances and Palestinian rescue workers.

DOC.HEAD: With Shaky Economy, Dollar Becomes Currency of Choice in Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar, the hated and admired symbol of American power, is the currency of choice on the streets of Baghdad, where U.N. sanctions have rattled the already shaky Iraqi economy. In ever-increasing numbers, Iraqis approach foreigners, risking lengthy prison sentences to buy dollars at black-market rates that have almost doubled in three months. At the same time, some merchants play the dangerous game of asking customers to give them something other than the new 25-dinar notes bearing the likeness of President Saddam Hussein. Western diplomats suggested that reflects a fear the dinar could lose its value if Saddam is toppled after a U.S.-led attack or in a coup. ``The common man is concerned about his future and the future of his family. He recognizes the possibility that Saddam might fail and places his bets accordingly,'' said one Asian diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. At official rates, one Iraqi dinar is worth $3 in Iraq. But on the streets of Baghdad, one dollar can buy five Iraqi dinars and in some outlying areas the going rate is reportedly six or seven dinars. ``It's a dollar economy,'' said one European diplomat, also speaking on condition of anonymity. ``There isn't much you can't buy with dollars. You can buy your way out (of the country), or you can buy your way out of the army.'' One Western diplomat said some major figures in the Iraqi business world are turning vast amounts of their assets into cash - and turning that cash into dollars. ``The weakness of the dinar is not linked to the weakness of the government, but to the weakness of the economy. The dinar's a paper currency based on the oil and oil is not being sold,'' the Asian diplomat said. Before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent U.N. embargo, the country earned more than 95 percent of its foreign exchange from oil exports. ``Sanctions are already hurting. On that I have no doubts,'' the Asian diplomat said. ``Almost the entire industrial sector has either ground to a halt or is chuggling along very slowly.'' Shortages of spare parts, imported raw materials and foreign technical expertise have left much of Iraq's industry running at only a maintenance level, Western diplomats said. Prices on everything from cigarettes to tires are soaring in the marketplace. Cigarettes that just three months ago cost one-third of a dinar, now cost 3.50 dinars. Tires now cost 300 dinars apiece, or $900 at the official rate. ``The level of frustration on the street is amazing. Everyone in the country has his life on hold,'' said one European diplomat. Food is still in abundant supply in Iraq, much of it smuggled in from Iran or looted from Kuwait. Store shelves overflow with consumer goods and delicacies still in their Kuwaiti packaging. Despite official Iraqi complaints about shortages of medicines, doctors in Baghdad say there's no problem with supplies. Western diplomats suggest Iraqi attempts to acquire more medicine in exchange for hostages is an attempt to bolster stockpiles for war. Last week the government announced a new decree imposing the death sentence on people convicted of hoarding food. Some diplomats believe it is aimed mainly at discouraging large-scale smuggling. Others believe the government itself is heavily involved in the smuggling and simply wants to excercise more control on consumption, distribution and profiteering. Western and Asian diplomats say they cannot accurately assess how long Iraq can hold out under the pressure of sanctions alone. ``I don't think one can set a time limit,'' said one Asian diplomat. ``You have to take into account the way this society functions. ``There's no way for the people to express their unhappiness with the government. But on the other hand, Saddam Hussein and the leadership all realize that they can push the people only so far,'' he added. One Western diplomat was more blunt in his assessment of the sanctions: ``They'll not work in time to avoid war.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Can Stay; Activated Army Couple Gets Reprieve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Twila Schamer will get to be a mom again. Mrs. Schamer and her husband, Christopher, parents of a 9-week-old son, were among 705 reservists with the Army's 50th General Hospital Unit who were called to active duty last week for a minimum of six months. On Saturday, however, at a briefing for the unit's members and their families at Fort Lewis, south of Tacoma, Mrs. Schamer was told she had been granted a hardship exemption to allow her to stay home and care for her baby, Jacob. ``It's kind of a mixed blessing,'' she said. ``For me, it's nice that I get to stay home with Jake. But my husband's still leaving, so it's hard.'' Christopher Schamer, 25, is a communications specialist whose duties include setting up the hospital's phone service. Mrs. Schamer, 26, is a sergeant who works as an administrative assistant in the nursing division. The Schamers reported Saturday to Fort Lewis, where they were scheduled to go through orientation and training for deployment to the Persian Gulf or a domestic base in need of medical personnel. The Schamers initially planned to leave Jacob with his paternal grandparents in Bellevue, east of Seattle. The break with his family still will be hard, Schamer said. ``I'm really kind of dazed. There's a job to be done over there ... but I'm just getting used to being a father now, and feeling that I may have to leave that behind for six months really hurts me,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Case Stirs Woman's Battle For Dignity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: All Sharon Russell ever wanted to be was a nurse, but her weight nearly got in the way. After she was kicked out of nursing school in 1985, weighing more than 300 pounds, she sued the school and won. Now the case has moved to the U.S. Supreme Court and she's moved to the forefront in the fight for dignity for overweight people. ``It's going to take time. It's going to take patience,'' Ms. Russell said. ``And it's going to take people like me who have the guts to stand up and say, `I was humiliated - this is how I felt.''' A federal jury last year ordered Salve Regina College of Newport, R.I., to pay Ms. Russell nearly $44,000 in damages. An appeals court upheld the judgment and the school appealed its case to the nation's high court. The justices this week will hear arguments to decide a narrow, procedural point of law relating to the appeals court's standard of review. Although the decision, expected sometime next year, will have little bearing on the legal question of so-called size discrimination, it could determine whether the award must be paid. ``The important thing is more people will understand what I had to go through to get to this point,'' said Ms. Russell, now 26 and a pediatric nurse at All Children's Hospital in St. Petersburg. Ms. Russell maintains size discrimination was the sole reason for her dismissal from Salve Regina, but school officials argue she was unhealthy because she suffered from an eating disorder and was physically unable to handle patients. ``We don't dismiss students because they're fat,'' said Catherine Graziano, Salve Regina's dean of nursing. ``We dismiss students if they have behavior problems that make them unable to function as nurses.'' Ms. Russell said her 5-foot-6, 300-pound body didn't seem to bother administrators in 1982 when she was accepted at the small college run by the Roman Catholic Sisters of Mercy. After earning good grades through her freshman and sophomore years, she entered the college's nursing program. Her problems began the first day. ``My instructor took one look at me and said, `We're not going to get a uniform to fit you. You'll never get around a bed,''' she said. She said she was used as a ``human guinea pig'' in class to show students how to make a bed with a fat person or how to give a shot to a fat person. ``I would sit there and pretend it didn't bother me,'' she said, ``but it was just killing me inside.'' In December 1984, faculty members presented Ms. Russell with a contract to lose two pounds a week or face dismissal, and signed it because ``becoming a nurse was all I ever wanted.'' According to the school, Ms. Russell weighed 328 pounds at the beginning of her sophomore year, was down to 297 when she signed the agreement and back up to 303 during the summer of 1985. That was when Salve Regina notified Ms. Russell she would not be allowed to attend her senior year. With that, Ms. Russell slapped Salve Regina and five faculty members with a $2 million federal lawsuit alleging, among other things, handicap discrimination, intentional infliction of emotional distress, invasion of privacy and breach of contract. The judge dismissed all claims except the breach of contract allegation. A Providence jury sided with Ms. Russell, saying the school broke its implied contract to provide her with an education so long as she paid her tuition, maintained good grades and wasn't a discipline problem. The award reflected the cost of having to repeat her junior year at St. Joseph's College in West Hartford, Conn., and the lost earnings from spending an extra year in school. In upholding the verdict, the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals noted the school forced Ms. Russell out of school ``because she was obese and for no other reason.'' Save Regina's lawyer, Steven Snow, disagreed: ``If we did anything wrong, it was in giving her too many chances.'' Ms. Russell completed her nursing studies at St. Joseph's and has been working in St. Petersburg for 2{ years. She had her stomach surgically stapled in one of her many failed attempts to slim down. Asked how she was doing at St. Petersburg, a hospital spokeswoman said Sunday: ``I know that she is in a supervisory position, so that speaks for itself.'' She's become an active fighter against size discrimination and was the keynote speaker for the 3,000-member National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance. Her message is simple: ``Accept yourself the way you are, work with what you have, go for it and live your life. My attitude is I weigh 285 pounds now - get over it.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Get Taste of Banking; Teachers Cash Checks Down Hall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Jim Fitzgerald bounded into the new branch office of the Brattleboro Savings & Loan Association, doffed his sneakers for shiny brown shoes and tucked in his shirt. It was a high school senior's best effort to look like a banker. Fellow Brattleboro Union High School senior Amy Kinsman was already behind her teller's window, tidying things up and getting ready for the expected Friday rush of teachers cashing their paychecks. ``I didn't even know I'd be doing this at the beginning of the year,'' said Fitzgerald, 17, who is eyeing a college major in finance or economics. The goal of the high school's career center is to merge school and the real world. A proposal by a marketing class to install condom machines in high school restrooms was shot down last spring. Undaunted, Career Center Director William Dennen pushed ahead with a day care center for the children of teen-age mothers and with Vermont's first high school bank. It was an idea that Dennen and business teacher Bruce Bergeron had been kicking around for about three years. ``Wouldn't it be great if we could really get a bank working down here?'' Dennen recalled the two saying to one another. ``No role-playing, the real thing.'' A real-thing bank might eventually issue the mortgage on the house built by each year's construction trades class. And it would give the students in Bergeron's advanced accounting class a shot a handling real money. ``A good (vocational) center is supposed to parallel what's in the community,'' Dennen said. Sure enough, the house built by last year's construction trades class languishes on the market in a New England-wide real estate slump. And sure enough, the hallway off the high school's cafeteria looks a bit like Main Street. There's the day care center, a flower shop run by horticulture students, a restaurant run by cooking students, a store run by retailing students and now the bank. Business management teacher Maribeth Cornell said she especially likes the bank. Cornell used to have to try to get off work on time every other Friday and fight traffic to the heart of downtown to deposit her paycheck. Now she walks down the hall to the bank's new BUHS Career Center Branch and hands her check to student tellers Kinsman or Fitzgerald. ``I'm a customer who reaps the convenience of it,'' she said after cashing her check last Friday. She said she marvels at the services available at the high school. ``About the only thing we don't have is a place to get your hair cut,'' she said with a laugh. ``We need that.'' After thinking about a student bank for some time, Dennen and the Career Center staff held a luncheon for local bankers and laid out their proposal. Robert Schrull, 36-year-old president of the Brattleboro Savings & Loan, jumped at the idea. ``We'll do it,'' he said. That was on a Thursday. Schrull got the OK from his board on Friday and gave the formal go-ahead to the school on the following Monday. ``The little guy came through,'' Dennen said of the Savings & Loan. ``All the others were sort of reluctant.'' The state came through with a $5,000 grant, the bank invested $20,000, the school's building trades program helped with the construction and the electronics class wired the alarm and security camera systems. A 27-year-old customer service representative at the Brattleboro Savings was named branch manager. Twelve of the 13 students in Bergeron's advanced accounting class sent resumes to Schrull. He interviewed all 12, and sent them letters giving pointers on their resumes and interview styles. While Kinsman and Fitzgerald got the two initial openings; eventually all 12 students who applied will get a stint behind the tellers' windows. Brattleboro Savings & Loan keeps it simple. It doesn't deal in junk bonds or high-stakes real estate investments, just savings and checking accounts, certificates of deposit and home mortgages for Brattleboro area residents. A small bank like Schrull's needs the support of its community. Dennen said it made as much sense for the bank to try to make friends with students at the high school - many of whom would be shopping for mortgage loans in 10 or 15 years - as for the school to get it students experience in banking.

DOC.HEAD: Growing Wreath-Making Industry Results in Theft of Tree Branches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Landowners in eastern Maine are angered by the illegal stripping of branches from trees by brush rustlers who sell their booty to wreath makers. ``Some people will do anything for a buck,'' said Leslie Thornton, assistant regional ranger for Maine's Forest Service. ``As the price of brush has gone up, more people are doing this.'' Along U.S. Route 1 in Jonesboro, bright yellow signs warn ``tippers'' - those who gather branch tips from balsam trees - to stay off property unless they have permission. Roadblocks along secondary roads have been set up to check the tippers' harvests, and details patrol back roads to discourage illegal tipping. What was once a way for kids to earn a few bucks is now a big business. Douglas Getchell, a 39-year-old Forest Service ranger in Whitneyville, gathered tips in burlap bags and sold them for 3 or 4 cents a pound when he was a child. Now, the going rate for tips is about 20 or 30 cents a pound, and a good tipper can earn more than $200 a day. About 2 million wreaths a year are produced in eastern Maine, making the area the wreath capital of the nation and pumping an estimated $15 million to $18 million into the local economy. Most of the land in the region is owned by Champion and Georgia-Pacific Corp., each of which owns about 450,000 acres. For a $40 fee, Georgia-Pacific lets anyone take branch tips from its land. Champion, meanwhile, divides its land in large blocks of 300 to 3,000 acres and auctions rights to tippers. Bids range from $300 to $1,000. Rangers say illegal tippers usually have permits from paper companies or written permission from private landowners to gathers tips, but often move onto other land where brush is more plentiful. The vast forests and zigzagging property lines across hundreds of thousands of acres makes enforcement difficult. Six rangers patrol the 1.5 million-acre district in Washington County. Tippers often carry a gun to make it appear they're hunting. ``Sometimes I'll catch them with sticks of tips nearby and they'll say, `It's not mine. I'm out here hunting,''' Getchell said. Greg Antil of Jonesboro and some friends last year pooled $1,000 to buy the tipping rights on a prime block of Champion-owned land only to have brush rustlers tip a portion of the full-bodied trees. He said tipping on land where rights have been purchased by others is like stealing their money. ``Nine times out of 10 they'll get away with it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stores Baren Despite Ambitious Reforms
With PM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Free-market reforms have tripled the prices of many items, but they are scarce anyway. Food sometimes is harder to find than in the starvation days of Communist dictatorship. ``Life is surely more miserable now than under Ceausescu.'' said Pascu Dumitrescu, a 68-year-old pensioner, pointing to empty stalls in a public market. ``The shops are a reflection of our lives.'' After a long search, Dumitrescu found a store that had bread, waited in line with other sullen shoppers and bought a bag of stale loaves. ``People will no longer stand it,'' said an angry man of 60. ``They are going to take to the streets again, but this time they'll be demanding food.'' When the government imposed price increases Nov. 1 to push the country toward a market economy, it agreed to freeze the prices of such basic food items as bread, milk and meat until Jan. 1. It also temporarily froze rents and energy prices. Controlled prices don't make food any easier to find. Poorly paid store employees sometimes sell subsidized food to black marketeers. The government said last week it would prosecute anyone caught doing so. Leather shoes, underwear and spare auto parts are a only memories. Refrigerators, televisions, radios and toilet paper are impossible to find without special connections. Romanians endured years of harsh rationing under Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who exported everything possible in order to pay off the foreign debt. When they began the protests last December that led to his downfall and execution, many assumed prosperity would follow automatically. The new National Salvation Front government diverted food intended for export to domestic use after the revolution. That, combined with donations from the West, created the illusion of relative plenty at the beginning. It didn't last. Even though prices are higher now, shops offer the same paltry selection of food, most of it canned, as they did under Ceausescu. In the farmers' markets, where food is available, sellers raised their prices long ago without waiting for the government. Marian Nitu, the deputy agriculture and food minister, estimated in an interview that food exports totaled about $20 million so far this year. Along with livestock, he said, ``vegetables, fruits and canned beef'' were going to buyers in the West and Far East. All are hard to find in local markets. Nicolae Tache, director of the public market where Dumitrescu was shopping, said meat had not been available for more than a week and blamed what he called a corrupt government distribution system. ``I have to bribe for delivery contracts to be honored,'' he said. At another market in the main Bucharest district of Pajura, more than 50 people lined up for butter. Others waited silently for small rations of sugar. Rumors that a milk van was arriving spread through the crowdand another long line formed at the milk shop. The only available meat was six pig feet, coated with fine hairs and laid out on a dirty shelf in a food shop that also offered 2-year-old cans of squash, vegetable puree and spinach. Most shoppers bought half-filled bottles of mineral water. The driest summer in years added tap water to the list of scarce commodities. For most Romanians, it will be another Christmas without the turkey, pork, fresh feta cheese, apple cake and wine some remember from better times. ``I am terrified by the coming days,'' said Maria Radoi, one of the shoppers.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia, Malaysia Balk at Proposal For Force Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to add newspaper report that meeting on resolution will probably be Thursday, details. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `In other...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON12, BOG1
DOC.TEXT: The United States failed on Saturday to persuade Colombia and Malaysia immediately to back a proposed U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq. But U.S. officials said the resolution would be presented to the Security Council this week. President Bush, who returned from Europe early Saturday, said he was confident of broad support for the proposed resolution. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has been lobbying world leaders for votes, is expected to preside over the debate when the foreign ministers of most of the 15 council members assemble at the United Nations at midweek, the U.S. officials said on condition of anonymity. The Malaysian foreign minister, who met with Baker in Los Angeles, told reporters he believed the meeting on the resolution would take place Thursday. The Los Angeles Times also reported in Sunday's editions that the resolution would probably be presented Thursday. The United States wants a meeting before the end of November, when it gives up its council chairmanship to Yemen. That nation, the only Arab member of the council, has sided with Iraq in the past. The Washington Post reported Sunday that the United States began distributing a draft of a proposed resolution to the other four permanent members of the Security Council Saturday night that does not specifically use the word ``force.'' The paper quoted diplomatic sources as saying they believe the draft seeks to avoid objections to that term by using such phrases as ``all necessary means.'' In other developments, a group of 10 British women on Saturday won the release of relatives held in Iraq, and President Saddam Hussein promised to free ``a large number'' of Italians. Also, a group of 36 female nurses, most of them Irish, arrived in Jordan after being allowed to leave when their contracts expired, an Irish Embassy official said. He would not give the nationalities of those who were not Irish. Bush and Baker have been lobbying leaders around the globe to support a military strike to force Iraq from Kuwait. Bush ended an eight-day trip to Europe and the Middle East on Saturday. Baker on Saturday visited Colombia, a key member of the U.N. Security Council. After a four-hour meeting, Colombian Foreign Minister Luis Jaramillo said his government had not decided how it would vote on the proposed resolution. ``Finding peaceful solutions to conflicts is a fundamental thesis within Colombia foreign policy,'' Jaramillo said at a news conference with Baker. Colombia has voted in favor of all previous Security Council resolutions against Iraq. Baker later met in Los Angeles with Foreign Minister Abu Hassan of Malaysia, also a council member. Hassan said he offered Baker ``no promises,'' but said he would discuss the matter with the rest of Malaysia's cabinet ministers on Wednesday. ``I believe that there will be a meeting of the Security Council on Thursday, so there will be time to make a decision,'' he said. Bush said Friday he was confident he would get broad approval from the Security Council for the latest proposal, even though some council members have refused to back the use of force against Iraq. China is among the uncommitted and, as one of the five permanent Council members, it has veto power. The other permanent members are Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. Spain's foreign minister, Fernandez Ordonez, met with Chinese leaders in Beijing and later said: ``I've always had the impression that it was possible such a resolution would pass this month.'' But he made it clear his view did not result from discussions with the Chinese. Since Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Security Council has passed 10 resolutions against Baghdad, including one that imposed a global trade embargo. About 26 nations have deployed 350,000 troops in the gulf region. They include 230,000 American troops, most in Saudi Arabia, and 200,000 more are on the way. The multinational force faces an estimated 460,000 Iraqi troops stationed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. Thousands of people in London and Bonn on Saturday protested the military buildup in the gulf. Police said about 5,000 people marched through central London. They carried placards that said ``Out of the gulf'' and chanted anti-war slogans. About 6,000 people rallied in Bonn to demand a peaceful solution to the standoff. There were smaller protests in Toronto, Ottawa, and Newark, N.J. Iraq's state-run television reported Saturday that Saddam met for one hour with British women who flew to Baghdad last week seeking the release of husbands, sons and brothers despite advice from the British government against the trip. The broadcast said he ordered the Britons released ``in appreciation for the women's visit and the role of women in general.'' The official Iraqi News Agency reported that Saddam also promised Archbishop Hilarion Capucci that he would free ``a large number of Italian nationals.'' Capucci is the spiritual head of the 3,000-member Melchite-rite Catholic community of Jerusalem. Also on Saturday, a German Foreign Ministery spokesman said German hostages freed by Iraq were expected to return to Frankfurt on Sunday afternoon. In another development, an American soldier was killed Saturday in Saudi Arabia in a truck collision. The soldier was the 49th to die since Operation Desert Shield began Aug. 7. The soldier, who was not identified, was from the 628th Transportation Company, 553rd Combat Support Battalion, 101st Combat Support Group.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gunman Shoots at Israeli Tourist Bus in Eilat, Kills Four
DOC.TEXT: Four people were killed and an unknown number of others wounded in the Israeli border town of Eilat Sunday when a gunman on the Egyptian side of the border sprayed their tour bus with bullets, an Israeli Embassy official said. Isaac Bar-Moshe, the embassy's press officer, said the gunman escaped in a car that was waiting for him after the attack Sunday morning. ``We know that a man stood just inside the Egyptian side of the border, near the Eilat border stone, and shot at an Israeli tourist bus inside Israel. We know that four have been killed and many others injured,'' Bar-Moshe said in a telephone interview. ``I am told that the gunman was in unfiorm but I do not know whether it was police or army or what. We do not know the identity or nationality of the gunman,'' Bar-Moshe added. ``There was a car waiting for him and he ran away in it,'' he said. He said the gunman had been carrying a Kalashnikov rifle. He said he had no further details.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. To Seek U.N. Resolution This Week on Force To Oust Iraqi Troops
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, ``Secretary of State xxx to add reports that meeting on resolution will probably be Thursday; Edits to conform; SUBS 7th graf pvs, ``The Washington Post xxx to change letter to resolution; Pickup 8th graf pvs, ``The paper quoted xxx
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will try this week to win U.N. Security Council approval of a resolution authorizing the use of force to end the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait if peaceful efforts fail, U.S. officials said Saturday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has traveled the world lobbying for votes, is expected to preside over the debate when the foreign ministers of most of the 15 council members assemble here at midweek. Malaysian Foreign Minister Abu Hassan said after meeting with Baker in Los Angeles Saturday that he believed the meeting on the resolution would take place Thursday. The Los Angeles Times also reported in its Sunday editions that the resolution would probably be presented Thursday. Malaysia is one of the council participants whose position is uncertain in what could be a tough test of the administration's Persian Gulf policy. Before meeting with Hassan Saturday, Baker visited Bogota, Colombia, but failed to win immediate support from Colombian officials for a resolution authorizing force to oust Iraqi troops from Kuwait. The United States' one-month presidency of the Security Council ends Friday. Yemen, expected to oppose a resolution against Iraq, will take over for December. In Beijing, Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez said Saturday the Security Council could pass the proposed resolution before the end of this week. The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions that the United States began distributing a draft of a proposed resolution to the other four permanent members of the Security Council Saturday night and that it does not specifically use the word ``force.'' The paper quoted diplomatic sources as saying it is their understanding the draft seeks to avoid objections to that term by using such phrases as ``all necessary means.'' Kuwait will make its presentation against Iraq on Monday and Tuesday. The focus then shifts under Baker's guidance to the resolution authorizing force. The U.S.-backed resolution would be the toughest step taken by the council against Iraq since the Aug. 2 invasion. The positions of the Soviet Union and China appeared uncertain, but U.S. officials did not expect the two powers to block a resolution. Officials expected that the two would try to soften the U.S. approach before it was put to a test vote. The five Security Council members with veto powers are Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. The Soviet Union's U.N. envoy also said Friday that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze would attend a Security Council meeting this week to discuss Iraqi aggression - and to issue a ``strong, serious and precise Warning'' to Baghdad. Only Cuba is considered a sure bet to vote against the resolution. The Bush administration wants the most lopsided tally possible to demonstrate to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that the drive to liberate Kuwait has widespread support. The Soviet Union and China have not ruled out force. A senior U.S. official, declining to be identified, said earlier this month that the two countries had given assurances they would not block such a resolution. Yet Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave no direct assurances to President Bush at their meeting last week how the Soviets would vote. From the outset, Gorbachev has put more stress than Bush on seeking a diplomatic solution to the crisis and has sent his top Mideast specialist, Yevgeny Primakov, on missions to Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Carrying 13 Plunges Into Adriatic
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter carrying 13 people plunged into the Adriatic Sea off northeastern Italy Sunday morning, and everyone on board was feared killed, authorities said. Rescuers recovered two bodies and were searching for others, said officials at the Civil Protection Ministry. There was no sign of survivors, they said. The helicopter was rented by the Italian oil company AGIP. It carried a three-member crew and 10 technicians headed for an offshore platform. The helicopter, an SA330 built by Aerospaziale, crashed soon after it left the town of Marina di Ravenna for a platform about a mile offshore, an official at the Civil Protection Ministry said on condition of anonymity. He said everyone on board was feared dead. The cause of the crash was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Group Claims Suicide Bomber Attacked Israeli Patrol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Israeli army communique; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A pro-Syrian group claimed that a woman detonated a handbag packed with explosives Sunday, killing herself and several israeli soldiers. Israel confirmed the attack but said two soldiers were wounded. A communique issued by the Syrian Social Nationalist Party said Sunday's suicide attack took place inside Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in south Lebanon at 10 a.m. (3 a.m. EST.) It was the second anti-Israeli incident in Lebanon in two days. On Saturday, the Israeli navy sank a dinghy off the Lebanese coast, killing five guerrillas apparently en route to attack an Israeli target, the Israeli army said in Jerusalem. ``Fadwa Hassan Ghanem detonated her bomb-laden handbag as an Israeli patrol was crossing the road between Kfar Tibnit and Arnoun in the security zone. The entire patrol was killed and she was martyred,'' the SSNP communique said. It did not say how many Israelis were killed. There was no immediate word on the attack from the Lebanese police. But in Jersusalem, the Israeli army said two soldiers were on patrol checking a road near Beaufort castle when ``a female terrorist ran at them, strapped with explosive charge. She exploded herself, wounding two soldiers, one in the neck and another in the feet,'' the Israeli army said. Beaufort, a crusader castle that was a Palestinian guerrilla stronghold in Israel's 1982 Lebanon war, is situated three miles north of the border. Another Israeli military official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said the two soldiers suffered light injuries and that a Lebanese citizen also was wounded in the attack. Dr. Mickey Wiener, deputy head of the Rambam Hospital in Haifa where the wounded soldiers were evacuated by helicopter, said they suffered ear injuries from the blast and superficial shrapnel wounds. He described the soldiers' condition as ``light to moderate.'' The 440-square-mile zone, carved out by Israel in 1985, is jointly patrolled by Israeli soldiers and about 2,500 members of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia. In the dinghy incident, ``an Israeli navy Dabur patrol vessel, on routine duty Saturday night off the Lebanese coast, encountered a terrorist boat. Battle ensued whereupon the terrorist boat was destroyed and five terrorists killed,'' the Israeli army said in a statement. The radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command said three of its guerrillas were killed in what it said was a three-hour gunbattle with Israeli gunboats off Saadiyat, 12 miles south of Beirut. The SSNP is a coalition of Lebanese leftist and Palestinian groups waging a guerrilla war to dislodge Israel from its border enclave. The party advocates the merger of Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, pre-1948 Palestine, Iraq, Kuwait and Cyprus into a ``Greater Syria.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede CAIRO
Gunman Shoots at Israeli Vehicles; Four Killed, 24 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with reports from Eilat, Israeli officials, gunman infiltrated from Egypt, three soldiers, one civilian dead; Changes byline; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A gunman who infiltrated from Egypt sprayed four Israeli vehicles with assault rifle fire Sunday, killing four people and wounding 24, the army said. The army said the lone gunman killed three Israeli army soldiers and a civilian driver for the national Egged bus company on the Israeli-Egyptian border, about 15 miles northwest of the Israeli Red Sea resort of Eilat. The gunman escaped back into Egypt. A senior Egyptian security source said an Egyptian border policeman assigned to the area of the attack had been arrested as the suspected assailant. Earlier reports from Cairo said the gunman had fired from the Egyptian side of the border. In Amman, Jordan a fundamentalist Islamic group Sunday claimed responsibility for the attack. The extremist Islamic Jihad-Beit Al-Maqdes, or Islamic Holy War-Jersualem, said the attack was carried out by ``one of our units operating in the land of Arabism and Islam, the land of Egypt.'' Defense Minister Moshe Arens called the attack ``a most serious incident'' and said Israel expected Egypt to take all the necessary steps to prevent such assaults. A military commander identified only as Brig. Gen. D. said on army radio that an Egyptian man ``whose identity is not clear to us at this moment'' infiltrated into Israel at the distance of about 300 yards from the scene of the shooting. ``He entered a dry riverbed, reached the road and lay in wait on the roadside,'' the commander said. The assailant opened fire on an army van, containing just the driver, who was injured but carried on for a few hundred yards and stopped. Another military car, also containing only one person and heading from Eilat to a nearby base, was hit by several bullets. The soldier inside was mortally wounded, drove for a few hundred yards and died, the commander said. Next came a military bus. The driver thought there had been an accident and stopped. He got out with his weapon but was shot dead ``at very close range'' before he could fire back. Finally, the attacker fired on an Egged bus carrying civilians working at military installations in the area. He wounded a security guard, who shot back, hitting the assailant. ``We found signs of blood showing that he was hit. I think this prevented a heavier tragedy,'' the commander said. ``The terrorist apparently intended to board the bus and take it over. He (the guard) did not let him come on board. He climbed down through the door and shot him, and from that moment the terrorist began running away.'' Reporters at the scene saw a red and white passenger bus with its windshield covered with bullet holes. Police forensic experts were seen picking up bullets around the bus. Isaac Bar-Moshe, press officer at the Israeli Embassy in Cairo, said the gunman had used a Soviet-made Kalashnikov semiautomatic rifle. If the attack was indeed committed by a member of Egypt's uniformed forces, it would be the second. On Oct. 5, 1985, an Egyptian border police officer went berserk and shot dead four Israeli children, two women and an elderly man near the border in the Sinai Desert. Before Sunday, the latest attack on an Israeli target in Egypt was on Feb. 4, when gunmen ambushed a tour bus, killing nine Israeli vacationers. The attack took place on a desert road between Cairo and the Suez Canal city of Ismailiya. Egypt is the only Arab state to have a peace treaty with Israel. After the treaty was signed in 1979, Israel began withdrawing from the Egyptian Sinai peninsula, which it occupied in 1967. Between 1984 and 1987, two Israeli diplomats and six Israelis were wounded in Cairo in a number of attacks claimed by an Egyptian terrorist organization, Egypt's Revolution.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 100 Germans Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to correct that only 7 germans did not arrive; Pickup 3rd, `The release...'
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Germans flew to freedom Sunday aboard a chartered Iraqi Airways jetliner to Frankfurt, German Embassy officials said. About seven other Germans expected to join them from Kuwait did not arrive as scheduled and were scheduled to leave Monday, the German Foreign Ministry said in Frankfurt. They are the last remaining German captives. The release followed the Iraqi Parliament's decision - on Saddam Hussein's recommendation - to free all German hostages because Chancellor Helmut Kohl has stressed the need for peaceful solution of the Persian Gulf crisis. Those freed Sunday were the second large group of Germans to fly out of Iraq this month. Former Chancellor Willy Brandt took more than 150 home with him after he visited Baghdad Nov. 9. Former boxing cahampion Mohammed Ali, meanwhile, met with Saddam Sunday in a bid to secure the release of some of the hundreds of Americans held in Iraq, officials reported. They said Ali was received by Saddam in his heavily guarded presidential palace on the banks of the Tigris River. No details of the talks were immediately available. Ali arrived in Baghdad last Wednesday, accompanied by two aides and two members of a group called the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. About 300 Americans are still held in Iraq. Another 600 are in Kuwait, some in hiding. Saddam has said he will free all Westerners held in Iraq and Kuwait between Christmas and March 15. But the Iraqis have warned that the proposed releases would be scrapped ``if something would take place that mars the atmosphere of peace.'' The Bush administration has been lobbying world leaders for support of a proposed U.N. resolution authorizing force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Dispute Prompts Death Threats in South African Child Pageant
DOC.TEXT: An 8-year-old contestant in a child beauty pageant was the target of death threats after a dispute over whether she qualifed for the final round, a newspaper reported Sunday. The Sunday Times, in a front-page story, said undercover police and private security guards dressed as clowns patrolled Saturday during the finals of the Miss Ladybird beauty-and-talent competition to protect the child, Sharika Habib. ``The whole thing is a disgrace,'' the newspaper quoted competition organizer Deborah Pead as saying. Marie Habib, the child's mother, told the Sunday Times she received death threats over the phone. ``This was a case of sick minds and sour grapes,'' she said. The dispute involved an error in calculating judges' scores in a preliminary competitions, Mrs. Pead said. Sharika won her competition, but the error caused officials to declare another girl the winner. When the error was discovered, Sharika was reinstated as a finalist, but parents of other children objected, Mrs. Pead said. The winner of the final competition was 9-year-old Jolene Sylvester. The title carries prizes worth $36,000.

DOC.HEAD: Police Move Onto Campus, Triggering Fierce Battle with Demonstrators
LaserPhoto SEL2
DOC.TEXT: Riot police stormed a Seoul campus to break up an anti-government, anti-U.S. rally Sunday but were driven back in violent clashes with 5,000 protesters hurling rocks and firebombs. ``Yankees go home!'' yelled protesters. ``Oust (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' In all, some 15,000 radical students, dissidents, farmers and workers staged protest rallies in Seoul and 10 provincial cities. Dozens of protesters were reported arrested nationwide. A dozen protesters and police were injured in Seoul, but it was not known how many were injured overall. The protesters demanded an end to American pressure to open South Korean markets. Hundreds of riot police backed by armored vehicles firing volleys of tear gas stormed on to the campus of Konkuk University in Seoul. But the estimated 5,000 protesters fought back with firebombs, metal clubs and rocks. At one point, five policemen were surrounded by club-wielding students. One officer was seriously injured and carried away. A wood barricade erected by students was set afire. Windows at a school building were broken by rocks and tear gas shells. Demonstrators regrouped to continue their rally. Police then stayed outside the school in eastern Seoul. A large sign at the school showed Uncle Sam telling a Korean farmer: ``Let's have the key to the warehouse. I will control the food.'' Clashes were reported in the provincial cities of Kwangju, Taegu, Pusan, Taejon, Sungnam, Wonju, Chonju and Chongju. Peaceful rallies were held in two other cities. In Kwangju, police fired tear gas when about 1,500 protesters marched out of Chonnam University, demanding an end to international talks trying to reduce tariffs on farm goods, reported Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Most of Sunday's clashes erupted around campuses. Demonstrators staged running street protests in at least four cities. The protesters demanded that South Korea reject the ``Uruguay Round'' of trade negotiations sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. They accused the United States of plotting a new international trade order that would sacrifice South Korea and other small countries for its own interests. Public anger over trade issues has increased in recent weeks. Consumer and civic groups have vowed to launch a boycott against U.S. goods. In an address last week, U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg said negative views of America have become widespread in South Korea, threatening to poison economic and political relations with the United States. Opposition leaders have warned of major political unrest, urging Roh to initiate sweeping political and social reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Special Zones, Cradle of Reforms, Celebrate 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: China's first laboratories for capitalist reform, four coastal enclaves that have attracted both investment and corruption, celebrate their 10th anniversary Monday uncertain of their role in the 1990s. When Shenzhen, Zhuhai, Shantou and Xiamen were designated China's first special economic zones in 1980, senior leader Deng Xiaoping was just starting his program of shaking up the inefficient centrally planned economy. Deng wanted to experiment with limited free markets, Western-style management and foreign-invested joint ventures. But he worried about the ``flies and mosquitoes'' - Western social and political values - that would come in the new open window. The answer was special zones, areas set apart for foreign investment, or in the case of Shenzhen, created for it. Shenzhen, an hour's train ride from Hong Kong, was mostly rice paddies in 1980. It had 30,000 residents and no traffic lights. Now it has 1.5 million residents, and its high-rise, neon-lit skyline is modeled on Hong Kong. It has become the biggest and best-known special economic zone, home to nearly one-fifth of the 10,000 foreign-invested companies operating in China. Huge celebrations might have been expected for the zones' 10th birthday. Instead, there almost was no celebration at all. The real birthdate, in August, was ignored and festivities were scheduled for this week only at the last minute. Shenzhen officials invited Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin to attend, but there has been no word on whether he will go. The national media have said little about the anniversary.
