The Shenzhen Special Zone Daily has reported local meetings to discuss the anniversary's ``guiding ideology,'' and has published 15 approved slogans for the day. ``Work hard for new achievements in building a socialist spiritual civilization,'' reads one. ``The whole nation supports the Special Economic Zones, the Special Economic Zones serve the whole nation.'' Beijing authorities fear the zones, especially Shenzhen, have been contaminated by capitalist values and have failed to contribute enough of their new-found wealth to the rest of the nation. Shenzhen has become notorious for higher levels of prostitution, gambling and crime than most Chinese cities. Workers hired by contract rather than for life, as is customary elsewhere in China, work harder, are paid better and spend more freely. An ``anything goes'' atmosphere prevails. One hotel even opened a casino in 1985, even though all gambling is illegal in China. Authorities quickly shut it down. Chinese entering Shenzhen need special travel permits, as if for a foreign country. Still, the government fears the ``flies and mosquitoes'' have gotten out of hand. At a meeting in Shenzhen in February, Premier Li Peng called on the zones to ``show a new image of socialist culture and morals.'' Communist Party leader Jiang warned, ``They are not special political zones.'' Critics in Beijing also say the zones' prosperity has not trickled back to inland regions that supply them with raw materials. Many products exported by the zones are made inland, but the zones take a cut of the profits for their transit. Dozens of other cities now offer incentives to foreign investors, such as tax waivers and long-term land leases, that rival what the zones can offer. Other cities also have been designated to experiment with new reforms, such as converting housing to private ownership. The strongest blow to the zones' special place came in 1989, when their main patron, party General Secretary Zhao Ziyang, was ousted for allegedly supporting pro-democracy protests. Since then, the reshuffled party leadership under Jiang has made Shanghai and the Yangtze River valley the centerpiece of development plans. Jiang was party secretary in Shanghai before being named to succeed Zhao. A fifth special enterprise zone, Hainan Island off the southern coast, was established in 1988 with Zhao's backing. Jiang and Li both have said there will be no more. ``We must first concentrate our strength to run the currently existing special zones well,'' Jiang told a Hong Kong magazine in September.

DOC.HEAD: Bush-Salinas Discussion to Center on Free Trade
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari welcomes President Bush to his hometown Monday for a discussion expected to center on developing closer relations through trade. The two nations are negotiating a free trade agreement, which Salinas hopes will help Mexico grow out of the Third World into the ranks of developed nations. Bush is to arrive in Monterrey at about noon and travel 55 miles by helicopter to Agualeguas, the Salinas family hometown of 5,000 people, where they will attend a rodeo and meet privately for two hours. They plan to return to Monterrey afterward. Another private meeting is scheduled for Wednesday, and Bush will speak to businessmen in Monterrey, the country's industrial capital. A Mexican bishop was quoted recently as saying ``it is like dealing with sharks'' to negotiate a free trade arrangement with the United States, but a government official said: ``Bishops don't know much about economy.'' The official, speaking anonymously, said the Salinas government feels it can strike a satisfactory deal with the United States. Otto Granados, the presidential press spokesman, said: ``We think that within a year we can have the basis of the agreement.'' Salinas hopes Mexican industrialists can produce more and better products to compete with an expected flood of U.S. goods, and also find markets in the United States. Years of hiding behind high tariff walls has hurt the competitive ability of some Mexican companies. Since Salinas took office in December 1988, Mexico has lowered tariffs and joined the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs, which his predecessors had sworn the country would never do. U.S. products, from beer to cars, now can be imported by those who can pay the lower duties. ``Ten years ago, if a Mexican president had suggested a free trade agreement with the United States, people would have hanged him in the middle of the main plaza,'' a high government official said, on condition of anonymity. ``I think Mexican society has matured,'' Granados said. ``There is less fear of the United States and we have a more pragmatic vision of our relationship with the United States. ``There is a global tendency to form regional blocs. Europe is too concentrated on its own expanded markets, Asia is another bloc and we must look at our own regional possibilities.'' Mexico focuses its economic attention on the United States and Canada rather than on Central and South America. Granados said the presidents probably would discuss the drug issue only in passing, if at all. Mexico feels cooperation on the drug problem is at least as good as it ever has been, he said. Another question is the treatment of Mexican nationals working in the United States, a sensitive issue on both sides of the border. Migrant workers, legal or illegal, often are accused of involvement in drug trafficking and other criminal activities. Allegations of racism have marred relations in the past. Mexicans always have considered the United States a racist society. Recently, newspapers in Mexico have played up incidents along frontier with California, where several Mexican citizens have died trying to across illegally. Reports of Californians lining up vehicles along the border and turning on the lights to help the border patrol are seen in Mexico as expressions of racism. The government wants any free trade agreement to make it easier for Mexicans to enter the United States. ``Our claim is that the U.S. economic reality demands Mexican labor,'' an official said. ``Even with more employment facilities in Mexico, the U.S. salary levels will remain attractive to Mexican workers. What we want to do is make the flow of labor more rational.'' Mexican officials say northward migration is not permanent and that studies show nearly 90 percent of the workers return to Mexico, at least temporarily.

DOC.HEAD: Rally on 20th Anniversary of Japanese Novelist's Suicide
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 people, mainly from right-wing groups, rallied Sunday in tribute to novelist Yukio Mishima, who shocked Japan with his gory ritual suicide 20 years ago at age 45. Mishima, regarded as one of the leading Japanese authors of this century, had denounced the postwar constitution that renounces war and limits the emperor's role to that of state symbol rather than a living god. The rally participants pledged to follow his principles, said Toshio Sasaki, one of the organizers. After the rally, 1,000 people, including members of the Japan Student Union and the right-wing Neo-Nationalist Union, marched to the army base where Mishima disemboweled himself on Nov. 25, 1970. The demonstrators carried banners saying: ``Regain history and tradition!'' and ``Long live the Emperor!'' In a traditional gesture, they laid chrysanthemums at the gates of the base. Police said there were no reports of violence. Before his suicide, Mishima and four young members of his small, private militia took a general hostage and demanded that troops stationed at the base assemble on the parade ground. In a speech from a balcony, Mishima urged the soldiers to rise up to regain glory for the Japanese military and the emperor. But he was heckled by the troops. At that point, Mishima hurried indoors, stripped to his loincloth and plunged a dagger into his abdomen, in the traditional manner of suicide. One of his followers then decapitated him with a sword. At the time, many feared that Mishima's spectacular suicide could help revive the militarism that had driven Japan into World War II. But his militaristic views have little popular support nowadays. When Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu recently proposed legislation that would allow Japanese soldiers to be sent to the Persian Gulf in non-combat roles, but opposition was so strong he had to drop the idea. Mishima's novels, plays and short stories are known for reflecting the conflict between the West and traditional Japanese values. Among his best-known novels are ``Confessions of a Mask,'' a partly autobiographical account of a boy's self-awakening, and ``The Temple of the Golden Pavilion,'' the story of a young monk who burns down a Buddhist temple.

DOC.HEAD: Commissioner Orders Water Pumping Stopped From Only Lake
DOC.TEXT: Israel's water commissioner ordered pumps halted Sunday to save the nation's main source of water, the Lake of Galilee. The commissioner, Zemah Ishai, said the level of the lake, known in Hebrew as Kinneret, was less than 2.75 inches away from the level at which continued pumping would destroy the reserve. Ishai told Israel radio that he ordered water supplied instead from underground water reservoirs. Besides the lake, Israel also pumps water from two aquifers, but they are near empty from several years of dry winters. Israel radio said the northern port city of Haifa was expected to suffer water supply problems because of the decision. Ishai said Israel was negotiating with Turkey to import water to help fill used-up reserves. ``We have a problem of shortage, of an accumulated deficit in the water economy for dozens of years ... the demand in Israel is growing and the welcome immigration will increase the demand,'' Ishai said. Israel expects a million Soviet Jewish immigrants to have arrived by the end of 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Mussolini's Desk Set Stolen
DOC.TEXT: The silver desk set used by Benito Mussolini at the signing of Italy's 1929 pact with the Vatican has been stolen from his granddaughter's house, newspapers reported Sunday. Raimonda Ciano, daughter of Galeazzo Ciano and Edda Mussolini, was quoted as saying the set was taken early Saturday from her Rome home while she was sleeping. The richly decorated, 19th-century desk set includes an inkstand, inkpot, two candleholders, and a container for sand and ashes, which were used to dry ink on the page. Ms. Ciano said the set was of ``enormous emotional value'' to her, according to the Rome-based daily Il Messaggero. It was not insured, according to the accounts. Police said Sunday they had no information on the theft. The Italian fascist dictator used the set to sign the Lateran Pacts with the Vatican, Ms. Ciano said. In the accords, the Roman Catholic Church recognized the sovereignty of the Italian state, and Catholicism became the official religion. Ms. Ciano was quoted as saying the burglary was likely commissioned. The burglars stole only a few small objects apart from the desk set and did not search in drawers or closets, she said. The burglary was discovered by Ms. Ciano's brother, Fabrizio. On arriving at his sister's apartment around noon, he found the door had been forced open, the newspapers said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Chips Away at Controversial Reagan Legacy
DOC.TEXT: Much like the Cold War itself, the U.S. effort to roll back communism under the Reagan Doctrine appears headed for oblivion. In the wake of the new East-West agreement on vastly reducing conventional arms in Europe, what passes for superpower tension these days results from the continuing U.S.-Soviet competition in remote Third World conflicts. During the 1960s and 1970s, virtually the only guerrilla fighters were those operating in anti-communist countries, often rightist military dictatorships. That all changed under Reagan, and American conservatives cheered when Reagan embraced ``freedom fighters'' opposing leftist rule around the world. Now, after a run of four years, much of the Reagan Doctrine's vitality is gone. In vote after vote, Congress has, in effect, told the Bush administration that it doesn't see much sense in maintaining full funding of anti-communist rebel groups when the Soviet bloc has ceased to exist. The administration doesn't dispute the point, but said continued aid to the rebel groups gives the leftist governments they oppose incentive to negotiate peace. When Reagan took office, the only resistance movement receiving U.S. help was the Afghan mujahedeen. By 1986, United States was assisting the Nicaraguan Contras, Cambodia's non-communist rebels and the insurgency fighting Angola's leftist government. But even that aid is in peril. In a move that went almost unnoticed in the rush to adjournment, Congress passed an intelligence bill that dealt the doctrine another blow. The bill would halt, among other restrictions, $60 million in U.S. aid to Angola's UNITA rebels if the leftist government agrees to hold free elections and the Soviet Union halts its own weapons shipments to the Angolan armed forces. It also suspends a $13 million covert aid program to anti-communist rebels in Cambodia that will be replaced by a humanitarian aid program. And it cuts back aid to the Afghan resistance to $250 million, $50 million less than the administration request. The program would be cut off altogether if the Soviets agree to stop sending military aid to the Afghan government. Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said he's not surprised Congress now balks at administration requests for aid to rightist rebel groups. ``The Soviets have cut back on funding of their `clients' around the world and we are responding accordingly,'' he said. ``The Soviets are out of Afghanistan, the Contras won in Nicaragua, and peace talks are in progress in Angola.'' Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., feels Congress is too eager to shelve the Reagan Doctrine. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev may have won hhe Nobel Peace Prize, Hyde said, ``but he is still pouring in $650 million into Angola, and Soviet advisers are still very active there.'' Hyde said he regrets the mood that ``exaggerates the resolution of the Cold War.'' Peter Rodman, of the Johns Hopkins Foreign Policy Institute, agreed. The former National Security Council aide said U.S. assistance helped initiate peace negotiations in each of the countries where the United States was supporting a rebel group. ``Our strategy ought to be to complete the process,'' Rodman said. ``Don't leave them (the rebel groups) in the lurch. The next phase is a political accommodation. It makes no sense to penalize our side.'' The Nicaraguan Contras were the first rebel group to be axed by the Congress. Despite Reagan administration predictions of impending doom resulting from the February 1988 vote against the Contras, the eventual outcome was a major plus for Washington. Nicaragua's civil war ended and the voters used the ballot box to oust the Sandinista government earlier this year - achieving what weapons shipments to the Contras were unable to do. Reagan's decision to back the Contras produced the most controversial moments of his presidency. There were dozens of votes on Contra aid over the years, most of them cliffhangers. The excesses of subordinates led to the Iran-Contra arms and money scandal and bitter recriminations between the administration and congressional Democrats. Ted Galen Carpenter, director of Foreign Policy Studies at the Cato Institute, a Washington research group, said the Reagan Doctrine was misguided to begin with because some of the groups receiving U.S. support were actually undemocratic, having sprung from authoritarian traditions. Beyond that, he said the Reagan administration consistently oversold the dangers to the United States of leftist rule in Nicaragua. The Reagan Doctrine, he said, also involved Washington in regions where no vital U.S. interests were at stake. But Burton Yale Pines, a senior vice president of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group, sees the Reagan Doctrine as a `marvelous legacy'' because it proclaimed that ``the future belongs to democracy, not to Soviet-imposed dictatorships.''

DOC.HEAD: Police: Man Tried To Ship M-80 Explosives In Plane's Cargo Area
DOC.TEXT: A 52-year-old man was arrested early Sunday after police at Kennedy International Airport discovered that his luggage included four boxes of firecracker-like explosives, a Port Authority spokesman said. Jose A. Nieves of Puerto Rico was charged with first-degree possession of a weapon and first-degree reckless endangerment, said the spokesman, Armando Arrastia. Pan Am Flight 448 bound for Miami was being boarded at about 7:50 a.m. as a baggage handler loaded the cargo area of the plane with baggage, he said. When he grabbed one box, which already had a small break in it, it ripped open and M-80s - a sort of strong firecracker - began falling across the belly of the plane, said Port Authority Officer Kevin Devlin. Three other boxes were also found. Passengers were then removed from the plane while the cargo area was searched for any other explosives, Arrastia said. Authorities said he purchased the explosives in Chinatown and apparently just intended to take them home with him. Purchase of any firecrackers is illegal in New York. Nieves was planning to fly to Miami before connecting to a flight for San Juan, Puerto Rico, Devlin said. The FBI and Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were investigating.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the NEW YORK-dated last item in AM-People, sent Nov. 23 as a0563, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Friday that a self-portrait of Marilyn Monroe would be auctioned with 35 other art works by famous people who enjoyed art as a hobby. The original works of art, which actually number 40 including the Monroe self-portrait, will not be sold. Instead, artists' proofs, high-quality reproductions of just seven of the 40 artworks, will be auctioned Tuesday. On the auction block are copies of works by James Dean, David Bowie, Tennessee Williams, Billy Dee Williams, Charles Bronson, Jeff Bridges and e.e. cummings, said Antonio Capretta, a co-founder of Twice Gifted, the group that organized the benefit.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Cast Ballots in Presidential Elections
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Poles on their way to church and on morning strolls with dogs and children lined up at voting stations nationwide Sunday to cast ballots in the country's first popular election for president. ``I was so excited I couldn't sleep last night,'' said Antonina Kaminska, a Warsaw seamstress who voted for Solidarity leader Lech Walesa. ``Walesa is a charismatic leader who gives all of Poland hope,'' she said on the dreary gray morning. The elections pit Walesa against his former ally, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Polish emigre Stanislaw Tyminski and three other candidates. The campaign had become increasingly caustic, and candidates engaged in Western-style mudslinging. Walesa led in pre-election polls. Stanislawa Kloskowska, a retired teacher from Walesa's home city of Gdansk, said she voted for the Baltic port's most famous native son. ``It was very easy to choose Lech Walesa,'' she said. ``He started everything here and we expect him to complete his job.'' Several people said they voted for Tyminski, a businessman who said he had made millions in Canada and Peru and pledged to build a ``democracy of money.'' His wealth is attractive to many Poles, who are struggling with a radical economic reform program implemented by the Mazowiecki government. It has cut real income by 35 percent and put about 1 million people out of work. ``For a year too little attention was paid to economy,'' said Wladyslaw Skarbek, 41, a researcher at the Polish Academy of Sciences in Warsaw. ``That's why I voted for Tyminski - as an outsider he will devote less time to politics and more to the economy.'' While many voiced support for Walesa, others expressed concern that the Nobel laureate would become a demagogue. His opponents have drawn crowns and even Hitler-like moustaches on Walesa campaign posters. Walesa's impetuous nature and campaign pledges - he promises to wield an ``ax'' to cut former Communists out of Poland's industry and government - have drawn sharp criticism from those who think the country should take a more cautious approach to reform. ``I am afraid of Walesa. He is an egomaniac,'' said Juliusz Baranowski, director of a new convenience store in Warsaw. ``The world doesn't need another ayatollah.'' Baranowski said Prime Minister Mazowiecki was not a ``born leader,'' but that he voted for the former Catholic journalist because his reserved, diplomatic nature would put Poland in good stead with the rest of Europe. The winner of Sunday's election will replace President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist general who imposed martial law to crush Solidarity in 1981. Jaruzelski is stepping down just over a year into his six-year term to complete the transfer of power to a freely elected head of state. While Poland was the first country in Eastern Europe to remove its Communist government, it is one of the last to hold free presidential elections.

DOC.HEAD: Monkeys Gladly Accept Invitation to Feast
LaserPhotos BK3,4
DOC.TEXT: They shunned the fried rice and their table manners left much to be desired, but otherwise Sunday's feast for 500 monkeys was a success. Yongyudh Kitwattananusom, owner of a hotel in the historic city, last week sent out elaborate written invitations to the hundreds of monkeys that inhabit an ancient temple in Lopburi. On Sunday, he set 50 tables, complete with tablecloths, and prepared a menu that included a vegetable salad, cashew nuts, eggs, fried rice and mixed tropical fruits. About 500 monkeys attended the feast. Yongyudh, who threw a similar beast banquet last year, hopes the event will help promote both his Lopburi Inn and the city, once an outpost of the vast Cambodian empire. Lopburi is 90 miles north of Bangkok. Several thousand Thais and foreigners gathered in Lopburi Sunday, initially scaring away the banquet guests. But, enticed by papaya leaves, the monkeys soon clambered down from their temple perches and tucked into the dishes. They ignored the chairs, positioned themselves atop tables and engaged in a lot of table hopping. Except for the fried rice, which they inexplicably turned down, the food was scooped up with gusto and washed down with soft drinks. The monkeys pulled tabs from cans and poured soft drink into saucers. Although table etiquette was minimal, the feast proceeded without fighting, possibly because there was plenty of food to go around. As part of this year's event, children aged 4 to 12 were invited to draw the monkeys. A first prize of $1,200 and two airline tickets to Tokyo's Disneyland was offered. Many Buddhist temples in Thailand have become sanctuaries for wild animals because Budhism forbids their killing.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Crashes into Adriatic, All Aboard Feared Killed
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter carrying 13 Italians plunged into the Adriatic Sea off northeastern Italy on Sunday morning, and everyone on board was feared killed, authorities said. It was the worst civilian helicopter crash in recent Italian history, media reported. Rescuers recovered two bodies before suspending their search Sunday evening because of choppy seas, said the port captain's office. It was scheduled to begin again Monday at dawn. The helicopter was rented by the Italian oil company AGIP. It carried a three-member crew, eight technicians and two employees of a catering service. They were headed for an offshore platform used to extract methane from the sea floor. The helicopter, an SA330 Puma built by Aerospaziale, crashed soon after it left the town of Marina di Ravenna for the platform about a mile offshore, said an official at the crisis unit of the Civil Protection Ministry in Rome, speaking on condition of anonymity. The cause of the crash was not immediately known. The rescue operation was complicated by strong winds that whipped the waves, officials said. The Italian Civil Aviation authority named a commission to investigate the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov, Karpov Agree to a Draw
DOC.TEXT: Chess masters and arch-rivals Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov began the second half of their chess World Championship where they left off - agreeing Sunday to a draw. The 13th game was adjourned Saturday night after 41 moves in five hours of play with a draw inevitable, according to the experts. Karpov, who is trying to regain the world championship title from defender Kasparov, proposed the draw by telephone through the intermediary of Dutch referee Geurt Gijssen, officials said, an option open to either player. Kasparov accepted. Karpov, playing white, would have opened Sunday's play with Kxd3. The 42nd move, sealed Saturday night in an envelope, was disclosed with the draw announcement Sunday. Kasparov, 27, and Karpov, 39, now each have 6{ points. They were tied at six points apiece after the first 12 games in New York from Oct. 8 to Nov. 7 - 10 of which were draws. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains the title. Monday's 14th game is the second of the French phase of the championship. Saturday's match in the main auditorium of the Palais des Congres in this southcentral city was the first in the championship series in two weeks. Karpov moved the queen's pawn to begin play again. The players went through a series of moves known as the Grunfeld defense, which was used in Game 9. Kasparov varied it a bit when he castled on the eighth move. The pair traded queens before the 20th move and were reduced to eight pieces each by the 30th. Karpov repeatedly left his chair in the early part of the match. Kasparov stayed at the board, hunched over in deep thought. At the adjournment, Kasparov had just taken a pawn to finish with five pawns, a rook and the king. Karpov had four pawns, a rook and a king but was about to take a black pawn to even things up again. Karpov waited more than 10 minutes as the five-hour time limit drew close before sealing his 42nd move. ``I thought it was reasonable exciting,'' said international grandmaster Mike Valvo of Perth Amboy, N.J. ``It was not a dull 25-30 move draw you would see in other matches.'' Karpov ran into a time problem as the time limit approached, with only nine minutes to complete eight moves. Each player is alloted 2{ hours for his first 40 moves. But Karpov moved eight times in his next seven minutes. ``Most of us who sat and watched thought that white had chances to win,'' Valvo said. ``In time pressure, Karpov seemed to let whatever edge he had slip away.'' Kasparov gained the title in 1985 from Karpov, who had held it from 1975. Their dislike for each other is well-known. The two men differ in temperment, looks, politics and even playing style. Kasparov considers Karpov a product of the Soviet system. ``Normally chess is a battle between two individuals,'' Kasparov has said in an interview. ``But in my case, with Karpov, it's a fight between two different mentalities in Russia. I identify him with the system I've been fighting.''

DOC.HEAD: Moves From Kasparov-Karpov Draw
With AM-Chess-Championship
DOC.TEXT: Here are the moves from Game 13 of the Kasparov-Karpov chess match Saturday. Karpov played white, Kasparov black: Grunfeld Opening, Exchange variation. Karpov Kasparov 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5 4. cxd5 Nxd5 5. e4 Nxc3 6. bxc3 Bg7 7. Be3 c5 8. Qd2 0-0 9. Rc1 Qa5 10. Nf3 e6 11. d5 exd5 12. exd5 Re8 13. Be2 Bf5 14. 0-0 Nd7 15. h3 Nb6 16. g4 Bd7 17. c4 Qxd2 18. Nxd2 Na4 19. Bf3 Nc3 20. Rxc3 Bxc3. 21. Ne4 Rxe4 22. Bxe4 Re8 23. Bd3 b6 24. Kg2 f5 25. gxf5 Bxf5 26. Bxf5 gxf5 27. Rd1 Kf7 28. Rd3 Bf6 29. Ra3 a5 30. Rb3 Bd8. 31. Rc3 Bc7 32. a4 Kf6 33. Kf1 f4 34. Bc1 Kf5. 35. Rc2 Rb8 36. Re2 Be5 37. Bb2 Bd4 38. Bxd4 cxd4 39. Re7 d3 40. Ke1 Rc8 41. Kd2. Rxc4. Game adjourned, draw agreed Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Heseltine Bid For Prime Ministership Gathers Momentum
LaserPhotos CHE1,2
DOC.TEXT: Michael Heseltine, who precipitated Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's downfall, said Sunday he was confident of getting the necessary votes to win the leadership of his party and country this week. But he admitted that some Conservative Party loyalists are deeply angry at him for his role in forcing out Mrs. Thatcher, who last week agreed to step down as prime minister. Heseltine, 57, and treasury chief John Major, 47, a right-winger who is reportedly supported by Mrs. Thatcher, appeared to be locked in a close contest in the race to succeed Mrs. Thatcher, with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd trailing. London bookmakers ranked Heseltine and Major as even favorites to win in Tuesday's ballot among the 372 Conservative Party legislators. Hurd was a long shot at around 10-1. A series of opinion polls in Sunday's newspapers indicated the party would win elections with him or Major as leader, but lose under Hurd. But Hurd, 60, argued that he had the best chance of unifying the traumatized Conservative Party. He said Heseltine was handicapped by deep anger among some legislators and party activists over Mrs. Thatcher's departure. ``There is a danger of a polarized result with the right wing clustering around him (Major) ... and the left wing clustering around Michael Hesetline,'' said Hurd. ``If that were to happen, then I think there would be a danger of the quarrelling continuing.'' Heseltine, in a series of radio and television interviews Sunday, argued that he has shown the same steely nerve that Mrs. Thatcher displayed in 1975 when she ousted Edward Heath as party leader. The Tories were then in opposition. ``Mrs. Thatcher and I have that characteristic of independence, some people call it guts,'' said Heseltine. ``When you believe somthing is right you do it.'' But he acknowledged, ``There are people who are cross with me, and I understand that.'' Mrs. Thatcher, prime minister for 11{ years, withdrew Thursday after she failed to get a big enough majority to stop Heseltine's challenge. With her husband, Denis, she spent the weekend for the last time at the prime minister's country residence outside London. A clutch of well-wishers cheered the 65-year-old prime minister as she left the local church after a morning service. She has not publicly endorsed any candidate. But London's Sunday Times, quoting ``friends'' of Mrs. Thatcher, reported she will vote for Major, with Hurd as second choice. If none of the three candidates receives a simple majority Tuesday, a third ballot will be held Thursday. Major and Heseltine both say they believe they are rolling up the 187 votes needed. ``They must be getting worried,'' Major said Sunday after Heseltine's campaign manager, legislator Neil McFarlane, said claims of majority support by Major's camp were bogus. Heseltine challenged Mrs. Thatcher after her deputy prime minister, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resigned and delivered a scathing attack on her combative stance with Britain's European Community partners. Mrs. Thatcher was already in trouble over the economy and a unpopular new local government tax, the poll tax, which Hesetline has pledged to review. He has the advantage of being the only one in the Cabinet not associated with the tax. The polls in Sunday's newspapers suggested the Conservative Party, which had trailed the Labor Party for the last 16 months of Mrs. Thatcher's leadership, would be up to 13 points ahead under Heseltine and about 4-6 points ahead under Major in elections. ``I've brought about a transformation in the Conservative Party's fortunes,'' Heseltine declared Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Winston Churchill, Grandson of Prime Minister, Visits Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp
LaserPhoto DHA4
DOC.TEXT: Winston Churchill, grandson of Britain's great wartime prime minister, paid a visit to the British troops in the Saudi desert - but jokingly admitted it wasn't his own finest hour. When he introduced himself to a British tank crewman as Winston Churchill, the Conservative lawmaker told photographers, the disbelieving soldier responded sarcastically: ``I'm Rommel.'' Gen. Erwin Rommel, the legendary ``Desert Fox,'' led Germany's Afrika Korp in World War II. The younger Churchill, in Saudi Arabia as part of a 14-member parliamentary delegation, rode in a Challenger tank named for his grandfather and visited the former prime minister's old regiment, the Queen's Royal Irish Hussars. The elder Churchill was no stranger to the desert - he fought in the Khartoum campaign in Sudan in the late 1800s. At a news conference in a camouflage tent, Churchill said peace in the Persian Gulf depended on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. He said the multinational force should not leave the gulf until Saddam's weapons of mass destruction are eliminated. ``We're not only talking about the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. We're talking about getting rid of Iraq's budding nuclear and existing chemical and biological weapons and long-range delivery systems,'' he said. Michael Mates, head of the delegation, said he would tell Parliament that that British morale is high and troops are ready to fight if need be. ``We have been able to assure them with absolute certainty that there will be no change in policy because the entire government is behind us, as is the opposition, as are all parties,'' he said. Britain said last week it would nearly double its force in the gulf region to 30,000 troops. That would make its contingent the second-largest in the multinational force, after that of the United States. The delegation is to meet Saudi Arabia's King Fahd on Monday and return to Britain on Tuesday. Fahd on Sunday praised outgoing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for the warm relations between the two countries during her years in power. Mrs. Thatcher announced last week she would quit, following a rebellion in the ranks of her party. In a statement, Fahd praised Mrs. Thatcher's ``firm stand'' against Iraqi agression. Mrs. Thatcher's party has said Britain's gulf policy will not change with the change in leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Panel to Blame NASA and Company For Hubble Flaw, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: NASA and the manufacturer share the blame for a flawed mirror that prevents the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope from focusing clearly, a member of an investigatory panel said. The NASA panel's final report on the flawed telescope will criticize both the space agency and the Perkin-Elmer Corp., said John Mangus, head of the optics branch of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space technology division. The report is to be released Tuesday. Mangus said the flaws in the manufacture of the 94{-inch telescope in 1980 and 1981 can be partly traced to the same management climate that led to the fatal explosion of the space shuttle Challenger in 1986. In both cases, he said, engineers were discouraged from bringing potential problems to the attention of their superiors. ``The culture has to be encouraged where you don't shoot the messenger,'' he said in a Hartford Courant story published Sunday. ``People don't like bad news, but what they like worse is not to be told about the problems. I know it has occurred on many of NASA's projects.'' An investigation into the Challenger explosion that killed seven crew members found that NASA ignored evidence of problems with O-rings sealing the joints of the shuttle's solid-fuel rocket boosters. Investigators faulted NASA for weak quality control and found that, under intense schedule pressure, engineers sometimes failed to report problems to managers. The immediate cause of the Hubble flaw was a technician's mistake, but program managers approved the quality-control program that allowed the mistake to escape detection, the investigatory board concluded. ``NASA certainly had the overall management responsibility,'' Mangus said. ``They did not have the management system in place to penetrate far enough into the system - otherwise this probably would not have happened.'' Board members would not release the report, but Mangus and other members told the newspaper that the report also says: - Mirror-testing that was done relied too heavily on a single instrument, which had been assembled improperly. Relatively simple ``sanity checks'' should have done to make sure the mirror-polishing system was working properly. - There was too little contact between those working on the mirror and NASA project supervisors who could have understood the test results. - Quality-control inspectors lacked the expertise in optics to understand results of some tests that showed a flaw in the mirror. The Hubble telescope was launched with the space shuttle April 24, and the focusing flaw was disclosed June 27. The flaw will be corrected during a 1993 space shuttle mission. The mirror is flawed because the principal optical instrument used to test it and measure the progress of the polishing had been assembled incorrectly by technicians working at Perkin-Elmer's optical division, which now is Hughes Danbury Optical Systems. Despite the flaw, NASA scientists have been increasingly pleased with the telescope's observations, which are better than can be made from instruments on Earth because the atmosphere doesn't interfere. NASA last week released new photographs of Saturn, showing details of an enormous atmospheric storm. The Hubble also has been able to photograph individual stars that exist in clusters, enabling the stars to be studied separately for the first time.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Gunmen Kill 16 People In a Punjab Town, Police Kill 9
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Hindu soldiers among those killed, 18 wounded in shopping center, neighborhood attacks. Pickup 7th pvs, `Bhatti said...'
DOC.TEXT: Sikh gunmen on Sunday raided a shopping center and a residential district in a Punjab city, killing at least 16 people and wounding 18, police said. A senior police officer blamed separatist Sikhs for the slayings. Elsewhere in the state, Sikh gunmen killed four others in separate attacks. Police, battling the separatists, killed nine suspected militants in separate incidents, the United News of India reported. Sikh radicals have killed an average of 16 people a day in Punjab in the last two weeks in ambushes, bombings and bus attacks, according to police officials. Since Jan. 1, the militants have killed 2,955 people in the rich farming state where they want to establish an independent nation for members of their faith. Among the dead in the city of Jalandhar on Sunday were two vacationing Hindu soldiers. Also, a physician and three patients were killed when the gunmen sprayed bullets at the shopping center where the clinic is located. ``It is really tragic, innocent people were killed,'' said the city's depurty inspector-general of police, D.R. Bhatti. Police said at least 18 people were wounded in the Jalandhar attacks. Bhatti said about six gunmen hijacked a car and fired indiscriminately at a shopping center. Their next target was a residential district. The group later abandoned the first car and hijacked another one to escape, Bhatti said. ``They opened fire at least at six places,'' Bhatti said. Jalandhar, a city of 1.7 million people, is about 60 miles east of Amritsar. Sikhs have a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab, which adjoins Haryana on the east and Pakistan on the west. Nationwide Sikhs make up only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Sikh separatists launched their campaign in 1982, claiming political and economic discrimination by Hindus who comprise 82 percent of the national population.

DOC.HEAD: Former Governor Reported Wounded in Attack
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti gunmen have wounded an Iraqi official who served briefly as governor of the occupied emirate, a spokesman for the exiled Kuwaiti government said Sunday. There was no immediate Iraqi confirmation of the Kuwaiti account, which was also reported Sunday by newspapers in Bahrain and Qatar. The Qatari report said the official, Ali Hassan Majeed, was killed. Abdel-Razzaq Saqer, a spokesman for the exiled government's Kuwait Information Office in Dhahran, cited recently arriving Kuwaitis as the sources of his report. Saqer quoted the escapees as saying a number of resistance fighters burst into Majeed's office in Kuwait and shot him in the shoulder, wounding but not killing him. He had no further information. Majeed was known for leading the brutal repression of Kurds in northern Iraq. The Bahraini daily Al-Ayam said Majeed was attacked near his accommodation at the Kuwait Hilton Hotel and sustained injuries in his shoulder. The Qatari newspaper Al-Sharq, quoting an unidentified Kuwaiti who recently fled the country, said three of the resistance men ambushed him outside a Kuwaiti home he had seized for his use. He was flown to Baghdad in an Iraqi helicopter but apparently died on the way because of his serious wounds, the report said. Majeed was appointed governor by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein after the Aug. 2 invasion and Iraqi annexation of Kuwait. Earlier this month, Saddam issued a decree naming Aziz Saleh No'man as the new governor, replacing Majeed.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Goes On Trial After Refusing Medical Help For Son Who Died
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Annita in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A woman who believes in faith healing and refused on religious grounds to get medical help for her son before he died of leukemia goes on trial Monday on a charge of negligent homicide. Annita Williamson, 43, was arrested after her 5-year-old son, Loren, died on June 2, 1989. She is free on $25,000 bail. Ms. Williamson is scheduled to be tried before a jury in 21st Judicial District Court. Ms. Williamson, one of 150 members of the Oak Grove Church of God, told Tangipahoa Parish sheriff's deputies at the time of her arrest that she believed prayer would heal the child. Neighbors told deputies that red splotches had covered the boy's body for several weeks. Coroner Vincent Cefalu said the child died of congestive heart failure resulting from untreated acute lymphocytic leukemia. Last month, Ms. Williamson turned down a plea bargain offered by District Attorney Duncan Kemp in which she would be put on probation in return for pleading no contest and promising to seek medical help for any of her living children should they become ill. Ms. Williamson, a widow, has three other children. Ed Wilson, pastor of Oak Grove Church of God, the church Ms. Williamson attends, described the church as a fundamentalist religious group. ``We're not a cult,'' Wilson said days after the boy's death. ``We're really mainline religious Christians with convictions that many people had 100 years ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Protesters Wounded in Clash With Police
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas and shotguns at stone-throwing protesters in a black township near Cape Town, wounding seven people, including a young boy, according to a news report Sunday. Four policemen were also injured in Saturday's clash with protesters in the Montana township, about 20 miles northeast of Cape Town. Residents were protesting the opening of a new township civic center, and had received permission to demonstrate in a designated area, the independent South African Press Association reported. But after the opening ceremony, protesters left the designated area to confront departing guests, the news agency said. When police told them to disperse, some protesters began hurling stones, the agency reported. Police opened fire with tear gas and shotguns, wounding six adults and a boy believed about 4-years-old in the legs, the agency said. Eleven people, including the wounded adults, were arrested, Press Association reported. The injured police officers were struck by stones. Three police vehicles and other cars were damaged, the news agency said. Many residents of black townships oppose local leaders, considering them collaborators with the white-led government and the apartheid system of racial segregation. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela told a rally Sunday that security forces were responsible for much of the bloodshed in recent months in black townships near Johannesburg. ``They find it easy to spill the blood of black people,'' Mandela told about 15,000 people at a stadium in the Tembisa township northeast of the city. ``I appeal to them to leave their guns and bullets at their barracks.'' He and other black leaders have accused security forces of instigating the township violence to destabilize the black opposition movement. The government and police have denied the charge.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: When country singer K.T. Oslin isn't touring, she finds life in the Music City a restful alternative, if a little slow. And the 48-year-old Oslin, who spent more than 20 years in New York City, says the biggest cities can seem quite small where love is concerned. ``New York City has 8 million people and women there say, `There's no men here, I can't meet anybody.' ``In a town of 1,800 they say, `There's no men here.' Of course, there it's closer to it that there ain't no men there,'' she said in a recent interview with The Tennessean. Oslin, best known for the hits ``80s Ladies'' and ``I'll Always Come Back,'' was born in Crossitt, Ark., and reared near Mobile, Ala. A Nashville resident since 1988, Oslin calls the city lovely but says it can be a little slow for her tastes. ``It seems to be a very married town, and that distrubs me. I was never so aware of being single as I am here.'' --- BOSTON (AP) - Gov. Michael S. Dukakis plans a trip to the other side of he world when he leaves office in January. Dukakis said he and his wife, Kitty, will travel to Australia and Hawaii for 4{ months. The two will lecture, study public health policy and relax. Dukakis has accepted a visiting professorship at the University of Hawaii for the spring semester and will speak on health policy, elective office and public service. The outgoing governor says he has no plans for a full-time job after May, but may teach part-time. ``We're both anxious to try a life that is less structured, less scheduled,'' Dukakis said in an interview published Sunday. Both Dukakises have signed with an agent to book speaking engagements. Dukakis, the defeated Democratic presidential candidate, did not seek another term as Massachussetts governor. He will be succeeded by Republic William Weld in January. --- BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) - There may be a recession on, but don't tell that to the Hollywood set. They're out in force, shopping for Christmas. Celebrity letter-spinner Vanna White of TV's ``Wheel of Fortune'' and actress Jill St. John were among the well-heeled shoppers at the posh Fred Hayman boutique on Rodeo Drive. Television and film stars were as common as tourists in the fashionable boutique on Saturday, according to Hayman publicist Lee Solters. Solters said St. John was in, buying presents for her first Christmas with husband Robert Wagner, whom she married in May. ``Vanna White bought a cocktail suit for her round of parties when she goes to Aspen for the holidays,'' Solters said, ``And sweaters too.'' Asked about the economic slump and the prospect of tight-fisted shoppers, Solters said there was no evidence of that on Rodeo Drive. More than 5,000 people visited Fred Hayman's on Friday and Saturday, a record for the store. ``Today, Mr. Hayman said he was more than delighted,'' Solters said. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Grace Jackson, the Olympic silver medalist and one of Jamaica's fastest sprinters, was married during the weekend to Hugh Small, Minister of Industry Commerce and Production. Jackson won the Silver medal in the 200-meter dash in the 1988 Olympics in Korea, second to American Florence Griffith Joyner. It was the third marriage for Small, a 49-year-old lawyer, and the first for Jackson, 29, who was Jamaica's Athlete-of-the-Year in 1986. The 150 guests at Saturday's wedding were headed by Prime Minister Michael Manley and included members of his Cabinet, the diplomatic and consular corps and several prominent athletes. Jackson said she plans to continue her athletic career for a few more years and will be running in the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Suicide Bomber Targets Israeli Patrol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with video of woman released; Pickup 6th, `Ms. Ghanem...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-Attacks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A woman suicide bomber detonated a handbag packed with explosives near an Israeli patrol in southern Lebanon Sunday. A pro-Syrian group said 12 Israeli soldiers also died but Israel said only two were injured. The blast occurred hours after an Israeli gunboat sank a dinghy off southern Lebanon, killing five guerrillas, the Israeli army said in Jerusalem. A Palestinian group said four of the guerrillas were missing but that one managed to swim ashore. It said the guerrillas had planned a raid in Israel. The escalating violence sharpened fears that southern Lebanon is becoming a flashpoint as President Elias Hrawi tries to assert government authority and end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. The government has no troops in southern Lebanon, where Israel controls a self-designated 440-square-mile security zone. But Hrawi's government has said it will seek to end Israel's occupation once it completes plans to get Moslem and Christian militias out of Beirut. Communiques issued by the Syrian Social Nationalist Party identified the woman as Fadwa Hassan Ghanem. They said Ms. Ghanem concealed the bag rigged with 55 pounds of TNT under a black chador she wore. The chador is the traditional feminine dress of Shiite Moslem fundamentalists, and covers the woman from head to toe. Beirut television stations later broadcast a 30-second videotape in which Ms. Ghanem said, ``I am going to give my life for the cause of battling the Zionist enemy out of our land.'' The stations said the poor-quality tape was provided by the group. It showed Ms. Ghanem dressed in camouflage fatigues talking into the camera surrounded by party posters and other paraphernalia. ``I ask all of you to follow my example. Do not shy away from fighting the Zionist usurper,'' she said in a shaky voice. She then stood up, saluted with her right arm and shouted ``Long Live Syria!'' - her party's motto. Ms. Ghanem detonated her bomb-laden handbag as an Israeli patrol of 12 soldiers with two tanks was crossing the road between Arnoun Kfar Tibnit and Arnoun in the Israeli security zone, one communique said. ``All soldiers of the patrol were killed and she was martyred,'' it said. But an Israeli army spokesman said only two soldiers were on patrol, checking a road near Beaufort castle, when ``a female terrorist ran at them, strapped with an explosive charge. She exploded herself, wounding the two soldiers, one in the neck and one in the feet.'' Beaufort, a crusader castle that was a Palestinian guerrilla stronghold in Israel's 1982 Lebanon war, is three miles north of the border. Dr. Mickey Wiener, deputy head of the Rambam Hospital in Haifa where the wounded soldiers were evacuated by helicopter, said they suffered ear injuries from the blast and superficial shrapnel wounds. He described the soldiers' condition as ``light to moderate.'' The Syrian Social Nationalist Party is part of a coalition of Lebanese leftist and pro-Syrian Palestinian factions engaged in a guerrilla war aimed at dislodging Israel from the border enclave. The party advocates the creation of a greater Syria by merging Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, pre-Israel Palestine, Iraq, Kuwait and Cyprus. Ms. Ghanem's attack was the 23rd suicide bombing in the Israeli security zone since 1985, when Israel carved it out as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla attacks. Eight of the bombings were staged by women. Meanwhile, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command said Sunday its guerrillas fought a two-hour sea battle with Israeli gunboats overnight off the coastal town of Sadiyat, 12 miles south of Beirut. A communique read over the Voice of the People radio station said four men were missing and that a fifth managed to swim ashore. Earlier the group had said that three of its fighters were killed. The Israeli army said in a statement that a navy patrol on routine duty spotted the guerrilla boat. ``Battle ensued whereupon the terrorist boat was destroyed and five terrorists killed,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Reveal Bush Role In Silverado Committee That Helped Homebuilder
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush served on the board of a Silverado savings and loan affiliate that helped a Denver homebuilder evade securities laws, according to federal documents quoted in a newspaper Sunday. The president's son already is awaiting an administrative law judge's ruling on whether he was guilty of conflicts of interest while serving on the board of the failed Denver savings and loan. The failure of Silverado in December 1988 is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. The Denver Post reported Sunday that it had obtained federal Securities and Exchange Commission documents about Bush's role on a management committee of Silverado-Elektra Ventures Ltd., the land development arm of Silverado. Silverado-Elektra was a joint venture between Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan, and Elektra Brokerage Co., a Denver real estate firm. S&Ls spun off land companies after federal deregulation of the industry in the early 1980s allowed thrifts to invest directly in real estate. Bush has declined to comment on his role as a board member. His attorney, James Nesland, said Bush served on the panelfrom late 1985 or early 1986 until 1988. Bush's actions on the oversight committee may or may not become part of a $200 million negligence lawsuit filed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. against Bush and other Silverado directors and officers, said FDIC spokesman David Barr. ``We're reserving that comment until it comes to trial,'' Barr said. ``That doesn't mean it's going to be an issue at the trial.'' The documents show the committee approved Silverado-Elektra's role as a phony buyer of some Houston residential lots from MDC Holdings Inc., a Denver homebuilder, the newspaper reported. The SEC documents indicated the Silverado committee knew Silverado-Elektra was to be a straw buyer. Straw buyers typically are employed to disguise property ownership, and do not use their own money. ``During the course of its internal review, representatives of the party (Silverado-Elektra) that purchased the residential lots from MDC stated that they would not have purchased the lots had they not felt assured of selling them to the third party,'' the documents said. The Post said that previous testimony by then-MDC president David Mandarich showed the homebuilder wanted to sell several hundred lots in the depressed Houston market to Bellamah Homes of New Mexico. MDC also wanted to buy lots near Castle Rock from a Bellamah Homes subsidiary. Because MDC is a publicly traded company, federal securities laws prevent it from exchanging properties with Bellamah and then recording a profit on the sale of the Houston lots. The SEC documents show MDC asked Silverado-Elektra to buy the Houston lots for $3.7 million. The same day, MDC contracted to buy the Castle Rock land from Bellamah Homes, and three days later, Silverado-Elektra sold the Houston lots to Bellamah homes, the documents showed. The SEC disciplined MDC in September 1989 for its handling of eight real estate transactions between 1985 and 1987, including employing Silverado-Elektra as a ``straw buyer'' and booking profits on the Houston sale. MDC neither admitted nor denied guilt to the SEC, but agreed to make changes in some of its accounting practices.

DOC.HEAD: Chicken King's Holiday Display Going Up With Inmates' Help
DOC.TEXT: The chicken king's Christmas display is going up at the state Capitol this year, and about 140 prison inmates are playing lighting elves. The inmates are working in shifts to put up 1.5 million lights on the state Capitol grounds for Al Copeland's display. Copeland is the founder of Popees Fried Chicken & Biscuits chain and last year bought Church's Fried Chicken. For the past few years, Copeland has put up the display at his headquarters in suburban New Orleans. Before that, Copeland's lights blazed around his home in the New Orleans suburb of Metairie. But after complaints from neighbors sparked a court case, the state Supreme Court said in 1985 that the display was too big and attracted too many gawkers to keep at home. ``It normally takes me about 60 days to do this and I use about 60 people. But ... they're giving me 16 days to do it,'' said Robert Theriot, who has overseen installation of the display for the past half-dozen years. Copeland went looking for a larger site this year, and state Agriculture Commissioner Bob Odom suggested that Copeland light up the trees at the Capitol to honor U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia. The inmates climbed ladders and scaffolds to deck the Capitol's old oaks, junipers, magnolias, azaleas and other trees and shrubs with lights. ``It's a real challenge,'' said Megan Becker, Copeland's designer and decorator. ``It's different. But the trees speak for themselves. Each is a work of art. You just string lights around them.'' The switch is to be thrown Thursday. ``It will be finished. It will,'' said Theriot.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Urges Kremlin to Move Slowly on Union Treaty
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper on Sunday urged the Kremlin to move slowly on the new Union Treaty, saying that only the Soviet Union's four Central Asian republics appeared willing to support it now. The treaty, which would redefine the central government's relationship with the 15 republics, was proposed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday to hold the nation together as the ``Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics.'' It would give the republics control over virtually all affairs except defense. But the newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda, said that if the central government presses for an early signing of the document, it will lose the republics of Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and Georgia. The newspaper also said it was unclear whether Russia, the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Moldavia would support it. Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, said last week Russia would not sign the treaty unless its ``real sovereignty'' could be assured and ownership issues over its bountiful natural resources are resolved. The independent Postfactum news agency on Sunday quoted Mikhail Goryn, a member of the Ukraine's nationalist movement Rukh, as urging that committees be formed at every plant in the republic to denounce the treaty. In addition to those republics mentioned by Komsomolskaya Pravda, Armenia has said it would not sign. The participation of others is in doubt because of drives for sovereignty or independence in all republics except Kirgizia. Komsomolskaya Pravda said that the Central Asian republics - Kirgizia, Tadzhikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenia - ``seem to be the sole supporters.'' Central Asia is the Soviet Union's poorest and most politically conservative region. Many republics have been bypassing the Kremlin and signing separate agreements with each other governing trade, cultural and political ties. Komsomolskaya Pravda took note of these ``bilateral treaties,'' saying they further complicate the picture and ``shift the signing of a new Union Treaty to a still longer perspective.'' In what could be regarded as the most overly optimistic assessment of the document's chances, the labor newspaper Trud quoted Politburo member and Communist Party ideology chief Alexander S. Dzasokhov as saying the Union Treaty is supported ``by at least 11 to 12 republics.'' Yet even with that upbeat conclusion, Dzasokhov told the newspaper, ``I think that we should use our patience and wait. I see no other way out.'' He also said that under the treaty, the republics would be sovereign ``in the broadest sense of the word.'' The blueprint was sent to the legislatures of the union and the 15 republics for approval. ``Not only the Baltic states, but also many Soviet republics, will not sign this treaty,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said Saturday in a televised speech to his republic. Komsomolskaya Pravda, considered a radical newspaper, generally praised the draft treaty as a balanced and sensible document that considers the nation's political situation. The central government does not set its requirements too high, so as not to scare away the tentative members of the new union. The newspaper noted that the draft contained potential obstacles, ``which are bound to raise questions and evoke heated debate.'' One provision says the ``powers of the union shall not be changed unless all the republics agree.'' Komsomolskaya Pravda identified that section as a problem, in an apparent acknowledgement of the difficulty of getting a consensus among the diverse regions in the nation of 285 million people. Another stumbling block is a part that says the union shall only delegate some of its powers to one or several republics if agreed upon by the rest of the republics, the newspaper said. The treaty says the union would be ``voluntary'' but does not identify who in each republic - voters or legislators - would decide whether to join. Each republic, ``as a sovereign state, has full state powers over its territory. Treaty participants regard the Soviet Union as a sovereign federative state formed as a result of the republics' voluntary union,'' the draft says.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Kills Four Israelis On Egyptian Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with further comment from bus passengers; EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CAI1
DOC.TEXT: A lone gunman slipped across the Egyptian border Sunday and ambushed a bus and three military vehicles, killing four Israelis and wounding 27, the army said. The attack was the third from Arab territory in two days. At least four Palestinian guerrillas were killed and two Israeli soldiers injured in incidents in Israel's self-declared security zone in southern Lebanon and off the Mediterranean coast. The dead in the border attack, three soldiers and a civilian bus driver, were shot on a road running along the Israeli-Egyptian border about 15 miles northwest of the Israeli Red Sea resort of Eilat, the army said. It said most of the wounded were civilian workers at an Israeli air base. The gunman, who used an automatic rifle and was described as wearing a uniform, escaped back into Egypt. He was shot by an Israeli security guard and trailing blood, the army said. An Israeli army patrol chased him, firing, but did not pursue him across the frontier, the army said. A senior Egyptian security source in Cairo said an Egyptian border policeman stationed in the area had been arrested as the suspected assailant. Israel army radio said the assailant's blood-stained flak jacket with ``Allah'' written on it was found in the area. It said the attack was claimed by the Moslem fundamentalist group Islamic Holy War-Jerusalem in a statement issued in Amman, Jordan. Israeli and Egyptian reports said the attacker was armed with the Soviet-designed Kalashnikov assault rifle. Karen Golan, 12, who was on the bus, said: ``I was sitting next to my father, near the back door. Suddenly we saw a bus half on the road, half in the wadi, and an army van. ``A man came out as though he was flagging us down for help. The driver slowed down and stopped and then the man opened fire. ``My father grabbed me and told me to put my hands around my head and get on the floor.'' She was slightly injured above the eye by fragments. Her father was unhurt. Israel television showed a woman named Rachel Fishbein, telling a relative on the telephone that she had seen a passenger's fingers blown off by bullets. ``We just lay there. Don't ask what happened,'' she sobbed. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir called on Egypt to capture and punish the assailant, and prevent further attacks. Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid called the attack ``very regrettable'' and said he hoped it would not affect relations between the two countries. Egypt and Israel have been at peace since 1979, and the border is less heavily defended than other Israeli frontiers. In another attack Sunday, a Lebanese woman carrying explosives killed herself and injured two Israeli soldiers in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in souther Lebanon, army reports said. The Syrian Socialist Nationalist Party, claimed responsibility for the attack and said 12 Israeli soldiers also were killed. On Saturday, a navy gunboat attacked a dinghy off the Lebanese coast that officials said was headed to attack Israel. The five guerrillas aboard were killed, the army said. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, a radical PLO faction, said Sunday its guerrillas were on board the boat. It said four were missing but that one swam to shore. Also Sunday, a pipe bomb exploded at a bus stop in the Jewish sector of Jerusalem but no one was injured, police said. In the attack at the Egyptian border, a brigadier general identified only by his first name, Dubi, said the assailant ``lay in wait on the roadside.'' The assailant's first two victims were soldiers driving alone in military vehicles, the army said. The third was driving an empty bus and apparently thought an accident had occurred, stopped and was shot at close range. Finally, the attacker fired on a red-and-white bus of the Egged national bus company that was carrying civilian workers at a nearby air base. A security guard on board was wounded but then managed to shoot the attacker, Dubi said. ``We found signs of blood showing that he was hit. I think this prevented a heavier tragedy,'' he said. ``The terrorist apparently intended to board the bus and take it over.'' Bus passenger Rachel Amor said the man did not look Arab, and wore a khaki-colored uniform like that of Israeli forces. He was ``putting ammunition into his gun,'' she said. It was the second such attack this year. On Feb. 4, gunmen ambushed an Israeli tour bus in Egypt, killing nine Israelis and wounding 20. The Egyptian government says the gunmen have since been arrested, and has hinted they are Palestinian. An army spokesman said of the 27 wounded Sunday, one soldier and eight civilians were hospitalized in Eilat and the Negev desert town of Beersheba. News reports said their wounds were minor to moderate.

DOC.HEAD: Five Die When Small Plane Crashes in Northern Italy
DOC.TEXT: A tourist plane crashed in a wooded area of central Italy on Sunday, killing all five people on board, police said. A man gathering mushrooms saw the plane crash and alerted authorities. Police found the five bodies at the crash site, they said. The nationalities of the victims were not immediately known, said a police officer in Amelia, speaking on condition of anonymity. The aircraft, an SIAI-208, was traveling from Rome to Perugia when it crashed in Amelia, 60 miles north of Rome. Police were investigating the cause of the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Between Israel and Egypt Has Always Been An Uneasy One
With AM-Israel-Attacks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egypt and Israel signed a peace treaty in 1979, but even if the two governments are no longer officially enemies, the people of the neighboring nations are far from friends. That was underscored Sunday when a lone gunman slipped across the Egyptian border Sunday and fired an automatic rifle at a bus and three military vehicles, killing four Israelis and wounding 27. The Egyptian interior ministry said it had arrested a border policeman suspected as the gunman. Egypt officially condemned the attack. Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid called it ``very regrettable'' and said he hoped it would not affect relations between the two countries. But analysts say incidents like this one reflect popular anger in Egypt over the Palestinian conflict, heightened by a sense that the conflict is being overshadowed by the Persian Gulf crisis. ``There is a growing frustration with the way the Israelis are treating Palestinians in the occupied territories,'' said Tahseen Bashir, a former spokesman for late President Anwar Sadat and a professor at the Foreign Ministry's school for diplomats. Bashir echoed an often-stated Arab opinion that West is unfair in not viewing Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip the way it views Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. He also said many Egyptians view Israel as being at least partly responsible for such attacks. ``Individual incidents will occur and are symptoms of the wrong policy Israel is pursuing,'' Bashir said. Sunday's attack took place on a road running along the Israeli-Egyptian border about 15 miles northwest of the Israeli Red Sea resort of Eilat, the Israeli army said. It was the third attack against Israel from Arab territory in two days. At least four Palestinian guerrillas were killed and two Israeli soldiers injured in incidents in Israel's self-declared security zone in southern Lebanon and off the Mediterranean coast. In Amman, Jordan, an extremist Islamic group, Islamic Holy War-Jerusalem, claimed responsibility for the Eilat attack. The claim could not be verified. The organization was founded in the Israeli-occupied West Bank in 1980 and has hundreds of followers throughout the Arab world. It is financed by Libya and Iran. Islamic Holy War-Jeruslam identified the perpetrator as ``the group of the martyred hero Suliman Khater.'' Khater was an Egyptian border police officer who went berserk on Oct. 5, 1985 and killed seven Israelis in the Sinai desert. He was sentenced to prison at hard labor, and four months after the shooting the government announced he had hanged himself in a Cairo prison hospital. Moslem fundamentalists, students and opposition parties hailed him as a hero and martyr. The Eilat attack was the latest in a string of recent attacks on Israeli targets involving Egyptian assailants or using Egypt as a staging ground. On Feb. 4, gunmen ambushed a tour bus, killing nine vacationers on the road between Cairo and the Suez Canal city of Ismailiya. Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa has hinted the gunmen, who were arrested, are Palestinians. Last December, Israeli troops killed five heavily armed Arabs who infiltrated from Egypt into Israel's Negev desert to allegedly carry out an attack. There has been no more information on the assailants, their nationalities or allegiance. Attacks since 1984 also included a number of shootings claimed by an Egyptian terrorist organization, Egypt's Revolution, allegedly financed by a son of Egypt's first president, Gamal Abdel-Nasser. The group, currently under trial for the attacks, killed two Israeli diplomats and wounded six Israelis and attempted to shoot at American diplomats. It is regarded as being an Arab nationalist organization with no ties to Molsem fundamentalists. Some of the defendents said in court they acted in protest of the normalization of relations between Egypt and Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Premier Warns Against General Strike
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov, under growing pressure to step down in the face of political turmoil and economic trouble, warned Sunday that a threatened strike would only make things worse. The opposition trade union federation Podkrepa said it would go ahead with a general strike on Monday if Lukanov does not resign by then. In a televised statement Sunday evening, Lukanov called the planned strike ``an extreme act,'' and said it could have serious consequences. He urged Bulgarians ``not to support the adventurers who, in their greed for power, are prepared to push Bulgaria onto the fatal path of civic conflict.'' The main trade union confederation said Sunday it would not back the strike. The opposition alliance, Union of Democratic Forces, said it would hold a rally Tuesday in support of the strike. A rally planned for Sunday did not take place. The continuingeconomic decline and shortages of basic foods and consumer goods have led to growing demands for Lukanov's resignation. There were daily demonstrations against the government over the past week. Lukanov and his government of former Communists narrowly survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Friday. It capped months of wrangling between the governing Socialists and the opposition over how to revive the economy and end the political stalemate. The Socialist Party, the successor to the former Communist Party, won June elections. On Sunday, small groups of protesters marched through Sofia and some tried to block streets as anti-government demonstrators had done for an hour Saturday. Police patrolled, some in riot gear. ``God won't fill the shops, but the strike will certainly empty them,'' Lukanov warned. Many staples are already rationed or not available, and an energy crisis has led to periodic power cuts. Lukanov said the government had taken all legal measures to ensure that transport, communications, medical services and deliveries of basic goods would not be interrupted. In a separate television appearance, the leader of the Podkrepa trade union, Konstantin Trenchev, rejected government claims that the strike would be illegal because of its political nature. Trenchev said a government must resign if it cannot secure a minimum standard of living for its population. Earlier, opposition and government leaders said they should talk about forming a coalition. Lukanov appeared to concur, saying it was necessary to ''find a formula for the cooperation between the political forces in the next week.'' Ivailo Trifonov of the president's office said on state radio that neither of the two main political forces could govern alone now. ``It is necessary that the Socialist Party and the Union of Democratic Forces sit at the negotiating table as quickly as possible to seek a way out'' of the crisis, he said. The Socialists hold 210 seats in Parliament. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces has 144 seats.

DOC.HEAD: Desider Galski, President Of Jewish Community, Killed In Car Accident
DOC.TEXT: Desider Galski, a leader of the Czechoslovak Jewish community, died in a car accident in Prague, a friend of the family said Sunday. He was 69. The accident occurred Saturday night after Galski was driving home from dinner, the friend said on condition of anonymity. Galski was alone in the car at the time. The friend was not able to provide any further details of the accident. Galski was president of the Jewish Community Council of the Czech Lands. He had served as president from 1980-1987 and was re-elcted after the November 1989 revolution that ousted Communists from power.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Votes `Only for Danuta'
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa, the leading candidate in Poland's first popular presidential election Sunday, joked with reporters that he only votes for his wife. A smiling Walesa walked to the polls after attending Mass with his wife, Danuta, and six of their eight children at St. Stanislaw Kostka Church in the Oliwa section of the northern port city of Gdansk. He was asked for whom he would vote as he strolled to the voting station 10 minutes from his house. ``I always vote for Danuta,'' he quipped. She smiled. Emerging from the station to applause from several dozen onlookers, Walesa told a slightly different story: ``I voted for the candidate who is supposed to win'' he said. Aides in Gdansk say Walesa had already begun removing some personal objects from his office at Solidarity union headquarters in anticipation of going to Belweder Palace, the seat of Polish presidents in Warsaw, or at least retiring as union chairman. Walesa has said he would leave the post if he loses the presidential election. Walesa held the hands of two of his daughters, Anna and Wiktoria, to and from church. After dropping them off at home, he proceeded to the polls with Danuta and their 18-year-old son, Slawek. ``I voted for my father. I had no choice, I didn't even think of anyone else,'' the young Walesa said. ``My wish is that my father can fulfill all his dreams.''

DOC.HEAD: President Back at White House After 10-day Absence
DOC.TEXT: President Bush returned to the White House Sunday after a 10-day absence and got ready to head off to Mexico. Bush looked tired as he emerged with his wife Barbara from a Marine One helicopter after a flight from Camp David. The Bushes spent an abbreviated weekend at the presidential retreat after arriving home early Saturday from a week-long mission to Europe and the Middle East, where they spent Thanksgiving with U.S. troops in the Saudi desert. The president planned to depart Monday morning for Monterrey, Mexico, and a two-day summit with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Another major trip faces him next week. He will depart Sunday night on a seven-day swing through five South American countries, Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lankan Rebels Capture Key Camp, 60 People Reported Dead
DOC.TEXT: Tamil militants captured a key northern jungle camp from the government, leaving at least 60 people dead on both sides, officials said Sunday. A rebel spokesman claimed the guerrillas killed 100 soldiers while overrunning the Manakulam camp, 160 miles north of Colombo, on Friday. He said 30 rebels died. The spokesman, who was contacted by telephone in London, identified himself only as Raju. Military officials claimed that soldiers killed 100 rebels, then made a ``tactical withdrawal'' on Saturday. They said at least 30 soldiers were killed and 125 wounded by the rebel's mortar assault. The conflicting reports could not be immediately reconciled. The two sides are known to have made exaggerated claims in the past about each other's casualties. With the garrison's fall, the government controls only five isolated and besieged military camps between Vavuniya, 25 miles south of Manakulam, and Jaffna peninsula, the most northern point of the island. The rest of the north and parts of eastern districts are controlled by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the rebel group that wants to set up an independent nation in the two predominantly Tamil areas. Fierce fighting had been raging around Manakulam since Thursday and the military claimed to have killed about 90 militants. But residents in Vavuniya said they knew of only 20 rebels killed. Military officials said Saturday the rebel casualties were inflicted during a counterattack Friday on a Tamil camp near the garrison, but conceded that troops have not found any of the bodies. On Sunday, military officials said 30 to 40 soldiers were killed and 125 injured by mortar fire. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the mortars were packed with large amounts of explosives and shrapnel. More than 500 soldiers were in the camp when it was attacked, they said. A Defense Ministry statement said the troops were fighting their way out of the jungles amid mortar attacks and heavy automatic gunfire. A Tamil Tiger statement said its fighters ``smashed army resistance and entered the strongly fortified camp triumphantly.'' The statement was faxed to news organizations in Colombo from the rebels' London office. Tamil separatists, who have been fighting for independence since 1983, say their ethnic minority is discriminated against by Sinhalese in jobs and education. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and control the government and the military. Tamils make up 18 percent.
