Most Sinhalese live in the central and southern districts of the country, an island off India's southern tip. More than 14,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Friends of British Hostage Demonstrate His Plight
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of John McCarthy, a British journalist held hostage in Beirut, on Sunday marked his birthday by staging a reconstruction of his prison ordeal. An actor sat in a mock-up of McCarthy's cell to show the conditions he is believed to be enduring. Friends of John McCarthy, a group that is lobbying for his release, staged the reconstruction in a warehouse studio in east London, two days before his fifth birthday in captivity. McCarthy will be 34 on Tuesday. McCarthy, who worked for the London-based Worldwide Television News, was abducted by gunmen on the night of April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut airport to catch a flight home. No group has claimed responsibility or made any demands for his release, but he is believed to be held by Shiite Moslem fundamentalists. The mock-up of McCarthy's cell was built using information provided by freed Irish hostage Brian Keenan, held with McCarthy until his release earlier this year, said Jill Morrell of the Friends of John McCarthy. She said the cell was modeled on one shared by McCarthy and Keenan, measuring about 15-by-13 feet. Actor Maurice McParland played the part of McCarthy, now thought to be held in solitary confinement, blindfolded and chained to a radiator, Ms. Morrell said. Candles on the floor were the only light, and the only towels provided had become hard and dirty, she said. On a hostage's birthday, the guards would bring in a triangular cake, with a match stuck in it, plus a bowl of fruit and nuts, and a glass of Coca Cola, Ms. Morrell said. Catherine Comerford, another organizer, said the group will deliver a petition to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Monday at the official residence at 10 Downing St. It urges the government to do more to secure McCarthy's release. All 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon are believed to be held by Shiite Moslem fundamentalists. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Macedonians Vote in Second Round
DOC.TEXT: Voters in Macedonia went to the polls Sunday for second-round regional elections after only 13 of the 120 seats in the republic's Parliament were filled in first-round balloting. Opinion polls conducted after the earlier voting on Nov. 11 gave a revamped communist party and a reform party loyal to Premier Ante Markovic a clear lead over nationalist parties. A total of 256 candidates contested the remaining seats in the unicameral regional legislature Sunday, the state Tanjug news agency reported. Twelve parties fielded candidates and three candidates ran as independents, the news agency said. Results were not expected before Monday, and possibly not until later in the week. In first-round voting, only 13 candidates won the absolute majority needed to secure a seat in the legislature of Macedonia, the poorest and southernmost Yugoslav republic. Results from 176 polling booths in 33 electoral districts were annulled after the vote two weeks ago due to irregularities, and first-round voting was repeated at those polling stations Sunday. A coalition of two parties supported by ethnic Albanians won six seats in the first round, compared to five for the reformed communist Party for Democratic Change and one each for the moderate Macedonian Socialist Party and the Alliance of Reformist Forces of federal Premier Markovic. Polling also took place Sunday in parts of the central Yugoslav republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina. About 80,000 voters were called to the polls for a repeat of first-round voting because of irregularities at 113 polling booths in 29 municipalities. Second-round voting in that republic is scheduled for Dec. 2. In first round balloting Nov. 18, nationalist parties won a sweeping victory over the ruling Communists. Elections in both republics were the first free balloting in those states in more than 50 years. In the northern liberal states of Slovenia and Croatia, center-right parties ousted the Communists in regional elections last spring. The largest state of Serbia and its neighbor Montenegro will be the last of the six republics to hold local elections. They are scheduled for Dec. 9. Thirty opposition parties have said they will boycott the elections in Communist-ruled Serbia, claiming the region's hard-line leadership is preparing to rig them. The independent journalists' trade union demanded Sunday that the state-run media in Serbia provide ``unbiased and fair coverage'' of the electoral campaign. State television has repeatedly accused the opposition of being ``traitors'' to Serbia.

DOC.HEAD: Voting Starts in Yucatan Election; Governing Party Favored
DOC.TEXT: Voters in the Yucatan state cast ballots Sunday in local races that test the government's promise to clean up Mexican elections. Polls indicated the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, was strongly favored among the southeastern state's 664,887 registered voters. The party has governed Mexico for 60 years. PRI officials said they could win all 106 mayoral jobs and 15 state legislature seats. It is the only party running for every post. But the leftist daily La Jornada reported that opposition candidates hoped to win control of at least 25 city halls. Only two small towns, Tetiz and Hocabe, currently have opposition mayors. Most other newspapers gave the opposition little chance to score major gains, outside of a possible victory in the capital, Merida, by the conservative National Action Party. Official election returns could be released in about a week. PRI officials have vowed the elections will be clean and democratic, in line with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's promises to liberalize Mexico's political and economic systems. But opposition leaders and local newspapers have alleged the PRI resorted to widespread cheating to help win recent state contests in Coahuila, Mexico and Hidalgo states. All the main opposition parties have accused the PRI of preparing to fix the Yucatan election. The PRI, in return, accused its foes of foul play, such as campaigning at polling places on election day. It also accused a National Action official of ``intimidating voters'' at one polling place. National Action charged the PRI of manipulating voter rolls and allowing the possibility of multiple voting. The leftist Democratic Revolution Party claimed bias in the distribution of voter credentials and in accreditation of poll watchers.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Union Leader Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Archie Brown, a labor leader who won a 1965 Supreme Court decision affirming the right of Communists to hold union office, has died at the age of 79. As an officer in the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union Local 10, Brown became nationally known as a target of the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1960. He was prosecuted by the government for his Communist beliefs and the case ended with his Supreme Court victory. Brown died of cancer Friday at his San Francisco home. Brown was born in Sioux City, Iowa, in 1911. As a teen-ager, he rode the freight trains to Oakland, where he became a newsboy. He also began his organizing career, launching a newsboys' strike in 1928. At 18, he joined the Young Communist League. His soapbox speeches earned him frequent arrests for disturbing the peace or interfering with police. Brown joined the waterfront union movement that emerged during a 1934 maritime strike. He and three others were charged with murdering a man in a fight at a San Francisco union hall in 1935. The man allegedly jumped out a window and later died. The four later were cleared of the charges, but Brown had to work as a longshoreman under an assumed name until 1941, when he gained the right to a regular job. He was appointed the Communist Party's state trade union director in 1946. In 1960, Brown appeared as a hostile witness before the House anti-Communist committee during hearings in San Francisco. He was ejected from the hearings and committee supporters accused him of masterminding anti-committee demonstrations. The following year, he was arrested and charged with violating a clause of the 1959 Landrum-Griffin Act that barred Communists from holding union office. He was found guilty in 1963, but a federal appeals court said the ban on Communists in union office was unconstitutional. The Supreme Court agreed, striking down the ban in 1965. Brown actively supported left-wing causes after retiring in 1977. He is survived by his wife, Esther, a sister, two brothers, three daughters and a son.

DOC.HEAD: Boxing Great Ali in Baghdad; More than 100 Germans Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to CORRECT that Ali, Saddam meeting postponed, sted that meeting was held; pickup graf 4 pvs `Ali arrived...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Boxing legend Muhammad Ali, on a visit to Baghdad, on Sunday pressed for the release of some of the hundreds of Americans held in Iraq. The visit came as more than 100 freed German captives arrived home after nearly four months of captivity and Iraqi officials said about 70 Italians were to be released Tuesday. Officials said Ali, former heavyweight champion of the world, was to be received Sunday by President Saddam Hussein in his heavily guarded presidential palace on the banks of the Tigris River. However, the session was postponed, and no new date was announced. There was no explanation of why the meeting was put off. An earlier report had said the two met. Ali arrived in Baghdad on Wednesday, accompanied by two aides and two members of a peace group called the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. Aides said he has visited some of the Americans held in a hotel in downtown Baghdad, but gave no details. About 300 Americans are detained in Iraq, and another 600 Americans are in Kuwait, either under detention or in hiding. One of Ali's associates, Arthur Morrison, said Ali was ``here on a goodwill mission'' and hoped to secure the release of some of the Americans.'' Morrison spoke to reporters on behalf of Ali, who is suffering from Parkinson's disease and cannot talk. Morrison based his comment on hand signals by Ali. The former champion, a convert to Islam and conscientious objector during the Vietnam War, has visited Moslem holy sites in and around Baghdad. It was not clear how long he planned to stay in Iraq. Prominent figures from more than a dozen countries with nationals held in Iraq have visited Baghdad, often bringing freed captives home with them. The 104 freed Germans and a Briton arrived in Frankfurt Sunday, many with tears streaming down their faces as they were reunited with families and friends. Rudolf Seiters, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's chief of staff, was on hand to greet the arrivals. The release of the Germans came after Iraq noted approvingly that Chancellor Helmut Kohl had stressed the need for a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. Those freed Sunday were the second-largest group of Germans to leave Iraq this month. Former Chacellor Willy Brandt brought 120 compatriots home with him Nov. 9 after he visited Baghdad. Meanwhile, Iraqi officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 70 Italians would be freed Tuesday through the intervention of Syrian-born Archbiship Hilarion Capucci, Syrian-born spiritual leader of the Melchite Catholic community in Jerusalem. An estimated 270 Italians are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. In Rome, the Italian Foreign Ministry said it had been told of the planned releases, word of which came a day after the Italian government sent a plane loaded with 25 tons of medicine to Baghdad. Shipments of medicine are allowed under the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq. Saddam has said he will free all the several thousand Westerners and Europeans stranded or held in Iraq and Kuwait between Christmas and the end of March - but only if nothing happens to mar ``the atmosphere of peace.'' The Christmas-to-March period is considered by many to be the most likely time for an offensive to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. In other developments involving the hostages: -Ten Greek nationals released from Iraq arrived in Amman, Jordan accompanied by a delegation representing the Iraqi-Greek Friendship Association, which secured their release. -A British opposition lawmaker left for Baghdad on Sunday, saying he expected to meet with Saddam. The lawmaker, Tony Benn, is identified with the left wing of the opposition Labor Party, and party leaders have distanced themselves from his trip. He told reporters he wanted to ``explore the possibilities of a peaceful settlement.'' -Two more British women left London Sunday for Iraq, where they will appeal to Saddam to release their hostage relatives. Hilary Jones and Anne Mansell decided to make the trip after hearing that a group of 10 British women already in Baghdad had won the release of relatives held in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Ivory Coast Voters Cast Ballots in First Free Parliament Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with voter turnout apparently light, ADD change in law to allow president to pick successor. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Voter turnout appeared light Sunday in the country's first multiparty parliamentary election, which opposition leaders claim was marred by intimidation and fraud by the party that ruled unchallenged for 30 years. Several people remained hospitalized after a clash Saturday between supporters of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's conservative Democratic Party and its hhief rival, the left-leaning Popular Front. About 4.4 million people registered to choose 175 legislators from among the 490 candidates representing 19 parties. Early results were expected Monday. The Democrats are assured of 40 seats that are unchallenged. They are expected to easily win a majority, reinforcing Houphouet-Boigny's huge victory last month in this West African nation's first contested presidential race. His sole challenger, Popular Front leader Laurent Gbagbo, accused the ruling party of rigging that election, in which the 85-year-old Houphouet-Boigny received 81.67 percent of votes. In the presidential ballot, Gbagbo's supporters smashed ballot boxes they charged were stuffed in advance with votes for Houphouet-Boigny. The government said the opposition disrupted voting because they knew they would not win. Early Sunday, about 200 armed soldiers surrounded Gbagbo's constituency of Ouragahio, 170 miles northwest of Abidjan. A spokesman for the opposition leader said the local government there had announced people could vote without producing identity or voter registration cards. There were few long lines at the polls Sunday. Polling places appeared more crowded in the presidential elections, which had a 63 percent turnout. At a voting station in Abidjan's affluent suburb of Cocody, some people said they were confused by the number of candidates. Before 1980, they could vote only ``yes'' or ``no'' to a single candidate. In 1980 and 1985, they could choose between two candidates. ``These elections are pointless,'' said one voter on condition of anonymity. ``Why do we need them when we have a perfectly capable president?'' The opposition was handicapped by the large funds the ruling party compiled from compulsory contributions from civil servants' salaries. Also, the government allowed voting by Africans from other countries working in Ivory Coast. The foreigners comprise at least a third of the 11.2 million population and almost all support the ruling party. In the central town of Bouake, Popular Front officials said their representatives were refused entry into polling stations to monitor voting. All parties fielding candidates are supposed to be able to watch the voting. The expected Democratic Party victory would appear to ensure Houphouet-Boigny can choose a successor, believed to be assembly speaker Henri Konan Bedie. Presidential aides have said Houphouet-Boigny wanted to resign in a few months. Under legislation pushed through the assembly this month, he would be succeeded by the speaker until the next scheduled elections in 1995. Previously, if the president died or retired the speaker could govern temporarily while he organized a special presidential election. The first election-related violence was reported Saturday in Abidjan's suburb of Yopougon. The suburb's deputy mayor, Mustapha Doukoure, a candidate in the election, said Popular Front supporters threw stones and beat ruling party members with sticks to stop them holding a peaceful march. He said 37 of his supporters were injured. The opposition party said, however, the clash occurred after men in three cars drove into a crowd of its followers leaving a meeting, injuring several. In the fighting that followed, 17 people were hurt and 10 of those were being treated in the hospital, a party spokesman said. Soldiers patrolled Sunday in Yopougon, the site of the first pro-democracy protests in Ivory Coast in February. Weeks of strikes and violent riots followed, forcing Houphouet-Boigny to legalize the political opposition. The demonstrations were precipitated by an economic crisis caused by corruption, overspending and slumping cocoa and coffee prices on world markets.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge Collapses, More Than 2,000 Homeless in Washington State Flooding
With Bridge Sinks
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Record rains, high winds and rampaging flood waters on major Washington rivers chased more than 2,000 people from their homes and destroyed a closed interstate highway bridge Sunday. One man was feared drowned when he drove past a barricade and into the floodwaters of the Snoqualmie River shortly before 2 a.m. near Duvall, about 15 miles east of Seattle, police said. The man's wife and daughter were rescued. At least 2,125 people were evacuated in six counties, Red Cross and local officials said. The Red Cross had 20 emergency shelters in operation, spokeswoman Hope Tuttle said. Sections of the old Interstate 90 floating bridge between Seattle and Mercer Island sank into Lake Washington, and a 125-foot barge broke free and sank against the U.S. 2 bridge over the Snohomish River about 5 miles east of Everett. ``My state is falling apart on me,'' Gov. Booth Gardner lamented after a helicopter tour of the region. Gardner added a dozen counties to five others for which he had sought federal disaster aid to recoup from sever floods two weeks ago. ``We've been looking at some of the past records, and we're definitely right up there with some of the worst there's ever been,'' he said. The new request covered Clallam, Chelan, Cowlitz, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Lewis, Mason, Pacific, Pierce, Thurston and Yakima counties. The previous request was for Grays Harbor, King, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom counties, where damage was estimated at more than $40 million before the latest flooding began. The most severe flooding appeared to be about 40 miles northeast of Seattle, east of Monroe in Snohomish County, where some houses were completely under water from the Skykomish River, Barlow said. Water lapped over one lane of Interstate 5 near Centralia and Chehalis, about 90 miles south of Seattle, slowing northbound traffic to a crawl, but dikes that collapsed during severe floods last winter were intact Sunday. Elsewhere, however, dikes and levees weakened by the floods two weeks ago fared less well. Water poured through a 150-foot break in a dike at 16-square-mile Fir Island, largely devoted to vegetable, flower bulb and dairy farms and surrounded on two sides by the Skagit River and on the third by Skagit Bay. About 400 people have been kept from their homes on the island, many for the past two weeks. Three-quarters of the island was under water. A dike break on the Nooksack River stranded about 1,000 people on Lummi Island, west of Bellingham and about 90 miles north of Seattle. The National Weather Service reported record flood levels on the Cedar, Skykomish, Snoqualmie, Snohomish and Stillaguamish rivers in King and Snohomish counties. It also reported an all-time record 24-hour rainfall of 5.82 inches in Olympia and 3.56 inches at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, a 24-hour record for November. County officials reported about 400 people displaced at one time or another in King County, at least 200 in Snohomish County, 500 to 1,200 in Skagit County, about 500 each in Whatcom and Pierce counties and 25 in Mason County. East of the Cascade Mountains, record windstorms caused widespread power outages in eastern Washington and northern Idaho, Washington Water Power officials reported. Winds in Spokane were clocked late Friday as high as 56 mph, a November record, the National Weather Service reported. The Silver Mountain ski gondola at Kellogg, Idaho, was unable to open for the season Saturday as winds gusted to 84 mph, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Storms Dump Snow and Rain on Western States
DOC.TEXT: A winter storm dumped at least 2 feet of snow in parts of Montana on Sunday while snow, rain and high winds were reported elsewhere in the West with flooding continuing in some areas. Snow advisories were in effect in Wyoming's west central mountains, Oregon's Cascade and Siskiyou mountains, and California's northern Sierra Nevada. Blizzard warnings were in effect in various parts of Alaska, including Nome, St. Lawrence Island, and the Bering Strait coast. Heavier snowfall recorded during the 24-hour period ending at 1 p.m. EST Sunday included as much as 27 inches near the eastern border of Montana's Glacier Park. There were no reports of measurable snowfall during the 6 hours ending at 1 p.m. EST. Rain continued to fall in other parts of the West Sunday. At 1 p.m., rain extended over the northern coast of California, western Oregon, southwest and southeast Washington and the northern portion of Idaho. Rain also was scattered over southeast Maine and central Arkansas. Heavier rainfall recorded during that period included 1 inch at Crescent City, Calif., and three-quarters of an inch at Mullan, Idaho. Flooding continued Sunday along northwest Montana's Yaak River, while flood warnings remained in effect in parts of Idaho and Washington. High wind warnings were posted for the higher elevations of southern and northern California, Nevada's Reno-Carson area and portions of eastern New York state. High winds reported Sunday included up to 70 mph in the mountains west of Reno, Nev., and up to 63 mph in Massena, N.Y., and 50 mph in Utica, N.Y. Record highs Sunday included 62 in Albany, N.Y; 74 in Chattanooga, Tenn.; 70 in Cheyenne, Wyo; 73 in Jackson, Ken.; 77 in both Denver and Galveston, Texas; and 81 in Dodge City, Kan. The nation's low Sunday morning was 6 degrees below zero at Warroad, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 7 degrees above zero at Warroad, to 89 degrees at Kingsville, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Sections Of Old I-90 Floating Bridge at Seattle Sink
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Ronald Matila ...' to CORRECT that workers not reported hurt. Picks up 8th graf, `Tugboats were ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Washington Floods
LaserPhoto SE1
DOC.TEXT: Sections of a closed interstate highway bridge across Lake Washington sank Sunday after a round of stormy weather, and engineers said the rest could collapse at any time. About one-third of the 1{-mile-long floating bridge across the lake sank, another piece sank about five hours later, and other sections appeared to be breaking loose, witnesses said. No injuries were reported. The four-lane bridge, which parallels the new Interstate 90 bridge that opened lasg rebuilt to serve as eastbound lanes for the roadway across the lake. State transportation engineers and police closed tht year, was beine new seven-lane bridge, which carries an average of about 110,000 vehicles a day, out of concern loose pieces of the old bridge could damage it. The old bridge floats on the water like a ship anchored in place, and has flotation chambers that can be pumped out. Dedicated in 1940, it was the world's first concrete pontoon floating bridge, said William Southern Jr., a spokesman for the Washington Department of Transportation. The new bridge's anchoring cables, look at the highly unpopular per-capita community charge, or ``poll tax.'' However, Kern noted that whoever the winner is, ``Britain's tense relationship with Europe won't become a great love affair.'' Hodgson said all the contenders ``have got immaculate Thatcherite credentials. They are all fully committed to privatization. They're all fully committed to lowering tax rates as quickly as possible and as is prudent,'' Hodgson said. ``You may say that Thatcher may have gone but the fundamental commitment of the Conservative Party to widen individual choice (by shrinking government) remains theirs,'' Hodgson said.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Foreign Minister Says Rough Treatment Incident Closed
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss official said Sunday that his government and the United States have ended a diplomatic spat over scuffles and shouting matches between President Bush's entourage and Geneva police. However, the White House said it had referred the matter to the State Department, which is expected to lodge a protest. In his comments, Swiss Foreign Minister Rene Felber said the White House acknowledged sharing the blame for the incidents, which were caused by misunderstandings over security procedures. ``The affair is closed,'' Felber said in an interview. On Saturday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States planned to file a diplomatic protest over the incidents during Bush's three-hour Geneva stopover Friday to meet Syrian President Hafez Assad. Felber claimed the White House backtracked in a subsequent phone call to Switzerland's ambassador in Washington, Edouard Brunner. He said that ``the White House simply thanked the Swiss ambassador in Washington'' for short-notice work in organizing the Bush-Assad meeting. The Swiss minister said the White House acknowledged it failed to tell Geneva security officers that some reporters and photographers traveling with the president should be allowed under a wing of Air Force One to watch Bush come and go, as is customary. During the scuffle, press people were pushed and shoved by security forces. Fitzwater said U.S. chief of protocol Joseph Reed was poked in the stomach with a machine gun. No one was injured, however. Roman Popadiuk, deputy White House press secretary, said Sunday the matter now rests with State Department officials, who were to file the protest. ``It's out of our hands,'' Popadiuk said. Fitzwater had called it the most ``brutal and vicious treatment by a security force in the last 10 years.'' He said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu was ``verbally abused'' by the head of Geneva security when he protested over the incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Emerge Victorious in Slovakian Elections
DOC.TEXT: Communists who were swept from federal power a year ago rebounded in Slovakia municipal elections Sunday to win more mayoral races than any other party. ``We hope these elections will allow us to show that we can also be around in a democratic and pluralistic system,'' Slovak Communist Party leader Peter Weiss said. However, President Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum party took nearly 30 percent of the council races in the northern Czech republic, where Communists placed third. In Slovakia, Communist candidates won 660 mayor's seats, or 23.2 percent of the 2,840 contests, chief statistician Pavel Husak of the Slovak Electoral Commission said. The Slovak National Party, which supports a separate Slovak state, won 43 seats, or 1.5 percent of all the races. The vote had been considered a test of separatist sentiment in the republic. The strong Communist showing appeared due in part to the emphasis on the candidates' personalities, rather than their party affiliations. The Christian Democrats were second with 541 mayoral wins, or 19.04 percent, and Public Against Violence with 476 victories, or 16.7 percent, said Husak. Other parties won the rest of the seats. The state CTK news agency said the Christian Democrats won 27.4 percent of the council seats in Slovakia. Public Against Violence was second with 20.4 percent, and the Communists third with 13.6 percent. Public Against Violence won the most seats in Slovakia in June regional and federal elections. The party joined Civic Forum to help oust Communists last year. But the its popularity has waned in recent months. It is blamed by many Slovaks for increasing economic hardships in the move to a market-oriented system. In the Czech republic, Civic Forum won 29.9 percent of 70,000 council races. Czech mayors are to be chosen by the councils. Independents were a surprising second with 25.2 percent, according to initial results announced by the Czech Electoral Commission. The Communists had 15 percent, and the People's Party of Christian Democrats were fourth at 14.9 percent. Other parties gained the balance of the spots. The official tallies are expected later this week.

DOC.HEAD: TV Producer of `The Flying Nun,' `McMillan and Wife' Dies of Leukemia
DOC.TEXT: Jon Epstein, producer of such television shows as ``Tarzan,'' ``The Flying Nun'' and ``McMillan and Wife,'' died after a 14-year battle with leukemia, a family spokesman said Sunday. He was 62. Epstein died Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said friend Barry Greenfield. A funeral was planned for noon Tuesday at Mount Sinai Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills. Epstein began producing television shows in the 1950s for the Ziv studios. His credits included ``Trials of O'Brien,'' ``Rat Patrol,'' ``The Outcasts,'' ``The Young Rebels,'' ``Three's a Crowd,'' ``The Sheriff'' and ``Owen Marshall, Counselor at Law.'' He also produced the television miniserie ``Rich Man, Poor Man'' in the 1970s. Epstein was executive producer of the ``Colombo'' TV series. He is survived by a brother, Danal, a nephew and a niece.

DOC.HEAD: From Three Rooms in a Potato Field to President's Palace?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 10-11 pvs, `It was not ...,' with 5 grafs to ADD background on Walesa. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `It is...' TRIMS thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 10 families of this mud-and-marsh hamlet have no doubt Lech Walesa should be president. After all, he's one of them. ``We know that from this man we can expect some results,'' said Stefan Walesa, the Solidarity chief's cousin and childhood playmate. Maybe, they say, their ``Leszek'' will use his presidential power to get the road to his birthplace paved. ``The rest of my family, my mother, my father, my three brothers all just now got on the tractor and went to vote for him,'' said Grzegorz Kosziowny, whose parents remember the schoolboy Walesa running across the fields. Nothing marks the beginning or end of Popowo, a two-hour drive northwest of Warsaw along the Vistula River. There is no shop, no school, no church. The town is not on the road map and no sign points the way down a rutted, half-flooded dirt road to the scattered farmsteads. Walesa grew up in a metal-roof, concrete-block home in a potato field. There was no electricity or water in the three-room house when he was born there Sept. 23, 1943. Walesa remembers the four-acre tract his father inherited from the much-divided family property as ``utterly deprived ... of anything approaching nostalgia.'' ``Our neighbors had avoided it, deeming it too dreadful to live on,'' he recalled in his 1987 autobiography, ``A Way of Hope.'' Walesa's father died in 1945, his health ruined by forced labor under the German occupiers. His mother married her brother-in-law a year later, and the impoverished family struggled in the devastated postwar countryside, sometimes without even bread to eat. It was not until 1967 that the 24-year-old Walesa put on his coat, took some money and, pushed by a broken love affair and a sense of wasted time, got on a train in nearby Dobrzyn. It went to Gdansk, where he took a job at the Lenin shipyard. Increasingly troubled by the workers' conditions and totalitarian communist rule - especially after the bloody repression of strikes in 1970 - Walesa lost one job after another to his activism. He was unemployed and outside the strikebound shipyard when he made his famous leap over the gate to lead Solidarity's founding in 1980. Held in custody after martial law in December 1981 and awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1983, Walesa maneuvered the Solidarity movement through years of repression. It took control of the government in 1989. On Sunday, three generations of cousin Stefan Walesa's family went to church and then voted for their ``Leszek'' for president. ``It is a wonderful feeling,'' said Stefan Walesa, a work-worn 53-year-old farmer. ``He deserves to be president. There is no other Pole who risked his life so much to defeat the communist system.'' In a living room decorated like that of many Poles with a painting of Polish-born Pope John Paul II and a small photo of the Solidarity leader, Walesa chuckles at the memory of the willful young Lech born next door. ``When he was young he wanted to do everything, he was involved in everything,'' he said. ``He became a national hero from such a small house,'' Stefan Walesa said. Lech Walesa returns to Popowo from time to time, most recently on Nov. 1 for All Saints Day, when Poles make pilgrimages to the graves of their relatives. Some say Walesa lacks the refinement to be president, but that is what appeals to many of his supporters. ``He is a real Pole, from a poor family like us farmers,'' said one middle-age woman emerging from the unheated social hall in neighboring Turzy Wilcza that served as the polling station for Popowo. ``The fact that he was born here is one of many reasons we voted for him.''

DOC.SECOND: Mother Can Stay; Activated Army Couple Gets Reprieve
DOC.NOTE: Eds:LEADS with 5 grafs to CORRECT that Mrs. Schamer was not given a hardship exemtipn but has applied for one. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The Schamers ...'
DOC.TEXT: Twila Schamer will get to be a mom again. Mrs. Schamer and her husband, Christopher, parents of a 9-week-old son, were among 705 reservists with the Army's 50th General Hospital Unit who were called to active duty last week for a minimum of six months. On Saturday, however, at a briefing for the unit's members and their families at Fort Lewis, south of Tacoma, Mrs. Schamer was told she would be allowed to stay home and care for her baby, Jacob. ``It's kind of a mixed blessing,'' she said. ``For me, it's nice that I get to stay home with Jake. But my husband's still leaving, so it's hard.'' Christopher Schamer, 25, is a communications specialist whose duties include setting up the hospital's phone service. Mrs. Schamer, 26, is a sergeant who works as an administrative assistant in the nursing division. Mrs. Schamer said she won't be sent overseas because her unit has enough other people with her specialty. She has applied for a hardship exemption from active duty and the request is pending. The Schamers reported Saturday to Fort Lewis, where they were scheduled to go through orientation and training for deployment to the Persian Gulf or a domestic base in need of medical personnel. The Schamers initially planned to leave Jacob with his paternal grandparents in Bellevue, east of Seattle. The break with his family still will be hard, Schamer said. ``I'm really kind of dazed. There's a job to be done over there ... but I'm just getting used to being a father now, and feeling that I may have to leave that behind for six months really hurts me,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Early Polls Show Walesa With Strong Lead; Second Spot Tied
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with results of early official returns. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `It was...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WAR51,52
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, who united Poles in their struggle against communism, won the initial round in Poland's first popular presidential election Sunday but appeared headed for a runoff, according to state TV exit polls. In a surprising development, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was in a close race against Stanislaw Tyminski for the No. 2 spot. Tyminski, a political unknown until recently, is a businessman who returned to his homeland only this fall after 21 years in Canada and Peru. The second-place finisher will enter a Dec. 9 runoff if the winner fails to gain an outright majority in the first round. Walesa, the head of Solidarity, had 41 percent of the vote, a 2-to-1 lead over Mazowiecki and Tyminski, according to the polls. The polls indicated Mazowiecki and Tyminski each had 20.5 percent of the vote, far ahead of the remaining three candidates. But early official returns from 270 polling stations, or about 1 percent of the vote nationwide, said Walesa led with 39.1 percent, followed by Tyminski with 23.4 percent and Mazowiecki at 20 percent. It was a stunning setback for Mazowiecki, a former Walesa ally who instituted unpopular economic austerity measures after taking command of Poland's first postwar non-Communist government. ``No matter what the election results are, we created a basis for a broader democratic movement in Poland,'' Mazowiecki told supporters at a students' club in Warsaw. ``We will continue the struggle for a democracy as we want it.'' He added later on television that he was waiting for ``real results, and not just some estimates.'' Pollsters questioned every 20th voter at 404 polling places around the country, or up to 15,000 people. The results were issued on nationwide TV minutes after the polls closed at 8 p.m. (2 p.m. EST). The poll indicated that farmers, who represent 40 percent of Polish society, deserted Mazowiecki en masse. Only 4 percent of the farm vote went to the prime minister, according to the poll. Farmers have been angry at the abolition of guaranteed prices for their produce under the government's shock economic reform plan. Mazowiecki also did poorly among workers, but led among intellectuals, according to the poll. Tyminski nearly tied Walesa in the Silesian mining district, the poll said. Coal miners there are threatened with layoffs and have been staging a series of warning strikes. A member of Mazowiecki's campaign, parliament deputy Jan Litynski, said the early exit poll results were ``a bit exaggerated ... Tadeusz Mazowiecki will undoubtedly reach the second round.'' ``Stanislaw Tyminski is the epitome of the (fairy tale) goldfish who promises to fulfill our wishes,'' said Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, co-founder of the pro-Mazowiecki political party Citizens Movement for Democratic Action. Pro-Mazowiecki newspaper editor Ernest Skalski said if Tyminski gets to the runoff, Walesa would win handily. ``But the very fact that he got to the second round would be a shameful episode in our political history,'' he said. Other supporters of Mazowiecki, the East bloc's first non-Communist head of government, seemed convinced that Walesa will win. ``Unfortunately, what we will see with Walesa as president is hyperinflation and chaos,'' said Marek Dabrowski, a former deputy finance minister who left the government to join Mazowiecki's bid. Walesa declined any immediate public statement. Jacek Merkel, manager of Walesa's campaign, said Walesa was still awaiting final results. He scheduled a news conference for Monday. However, Lech Kaczynski, the deputy Solidarity chairman and a top Walesa strategist, said, ``I'm rather disappointed because we hoped for at least 50 percent.'' He added, ``Now we have to deal with two phenomena, an absolute defeat of the government camp and ... this dangerous phenomenon called Tyminski.'' Tyminski, who promised to quickly cure Poland's economic problems, said on television late Sunday, ``I expected such a result. I am very happy.'' He accused state television of mounting a campaign against him and said he would challenge Walesa to a debate. ``In the second round, I will be supported by all those forces that have been supporting me, plus those which - I hope - will have a better chance to believe I am an honest man,'' he added. ``Tyminski conducted an American-standard campaign, breaking every rule,'' political commentator Ryszard Legutko said on state television. During the campaign, the state prosecutor opened a slander investigation against Tyminski, who had charged that Mazowiecki had committed treason against the nation with his economic policies. Mazowiecki's government is struggling to create a market economy and strip away the vestiges of 45 years of Communism. The new president will take over from President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist general who ordered martial law to crush Solidarity and imprisoned Walesa and Mazowiecki in December 1981. He also is expected to receive the symbols of authority from the still-existing World War II government in exile in London, which never recognized the Soviet-backed state. Jaruzelski, interviewed on television, said he did not see the early poll results ``as a great surprise.'' Mazowiecki was a longtime adviser to Walesa, and the Solidarity leader had tapped him to become head of the government in 1989. But they had a bitter falling-out, and the voting climaxed an often acrimonious two-month campaign that split the Solidarity movement into factions that supported the candidates. Mazowiecki was backed by intellectuals, who Walesa's populist campaign harshly criticized. There was harsh language on both sides, with Walesa calling Mazowiecki ``too slow'' and Mazowiecki accusing Walesa of destabilizing the country. The campaign also was tainted by the anti-Semitism of a fraction of the electorate, with oft-repeated rumors that the devoutly Roman Catholic Mazowiecki was Jewish or that Jews dominated his government. Walesa condemned anti-Semitism - resurgent in a Poland with virtually no Jews - and said he would not permit it as president. But he was accused of not doing enough to discourage such attitudes, and even of encouraging them with campaign statements that he was ``a pure Pole.'' The election ultimately became a test of political direction, the first in Eastern Europe to focus not on defeating communism but choosing between visions for the post-Communist future. Walesa, 47, is the charismatic leader of Solidarity, the first independent labor federation in the Soviet bloc, which led the anti-Communist rebellion. He contends even more reforms are needed more quickly or a social explosion is coming. Mazowiecki, 63, launched the region's most dramatic economic overhaul on Jan. 1 and says Poland needs his team to stay and finish the job through consistent, gradual change. He has accused Walesa of making promises he cannot keep, and some of his backers say Walesa would be a demagogue. It was the first time that Poles voted for a president by popular election. In the past, both under Communist rule and before World War II, presidents were elected by the Parliament. Retired office worker Genewefa Pawlak, a Walesa backer in Gdansk, said, ``We trust him because he fought for 10 years and he never let us down.'' The new president will serve a five-year term as head of state and commander in chief of the military, with powers to nominate the prime minister, dissolve parliament and declare a state of emergency under strictly defined circumstances. The other candidates were: Roman Bartoszcze of the Polish Peasants Party; former Communist Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz, endorsed by the Social Democracy party; and Leszek Moczulski, head of the patriotic-nationalist Confederation for an Independent Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Harry Connick Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Harry Connick Jr., the jazz pianist-singer who has been spinning through show business like a comet, now has landed here for two weeks, conquering Broadway. Connick, who is 23, opened ``An Evening with Harry Connick Jr. and his Orchestra'' at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater Friday night, the same night ``Swinging Out with Harry,'' a Dallas show on the tour Connick started in April, was on TV. He's also known for putting together the ``When Harry Met Sally'' soundtrack and he's currently making his movie acting debut in ``Memphis Belle,'' as a tailgunner who sings. The exuberant show should gladden the hearts of jazz fans. As a singer, Connick is the Mel Torme of his generation. He can croon but he isn't a pop singer, he's a jazz singer. Once, he sings scat. As a pianist, he has a heavy, percussive attack. He plays in a lot of styles, even stride and boogie woogie, but he doesn't touch jazz-rock. The 16-piece band he carries with him has a solid big band sound. It isn't as hard-charging as Woody Herman's herds - on purpose since its leader sings a lot and wants to be heard. But it swings and it has some classy, exciting soloists. Connick always announces them, in the best tradition. The amazing thing is that Connick gets the big band feeling and music so right and makes it sound so contemporary, never a careful reconstruction of the past. For a New Orleans traditional number he has musicians playing banjo and sousaphone, does some lusty ``second line'' dancing - like the people right behind the band in parades - and takes over the drums so drummer Shannon Powell can dance. Connick does a lot of things. He sings, then does a soft shoe in ``All I Need Is the Girl.'' It won't make one forget the number in ``Gypsy'' two blocks away, but it's charming. He writes music. He sings ``Forever For Now,'' with subtle, clever lyrics by Ramsey McLean. His encore was ``Buried in Blue,'' which he composed about his mother who died when he was 13. He has that on a record album but probably shouldn't use it as an encore. His manner is engaging, bordering on the corny sometimes, but not quite getting there. The audience sees through the ``ah shucks'' to the self-assurance and stays in the palm of his hand. After intermission, a 22-piece orchestra, mainly strings, is atop the steps where the band had been. After a couple of numbers, the band appears, in one long line, in the orchestra pit. Marilyn Lowey is innovative with lighting. Sometimes the audience sees Connick in silhouette, conducting. The show starts with him at the piano, then lights reveal the rest of the musicians. Joe Layton directed. Marc Shaiman conducts in Act 2. Alexander Julian has Connick dress casually, in a white, open-necked shirt, tan slacks and Navy blazer. Connick's father attended opening night, took a bow and had ``Danny Boy'' dedicated to him.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Wants Deadline on Use of Force; Iraq Threatens Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. officials saying they want a Jan. 1 deadline in use-of-force resolution, EDITS to conform; pickup graf 13 pvs `But Bush's...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA1
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials said late Sunday they want the United Nations to authorize using force against Iraq if it does not leave Kuwait by Jan. 1, and Baghdad's government threatened to rain missiles on Saudi Arabia if U.S. troops attack. Iraq also said it was mobilizing tens of thousands of farmers for military service, even though it is struggling to increase food production to offset the effects of U.N. sanctions imposed after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraqi authorities, meanwhile, were taking steps to make sure any shortages caused by the sanctions are felt in Kuwait, which Iraq calls its 19th province. The official Iraqi News Agency said food rationing would begin soon in the conquered emirate. U.S. officials seeking a U.N. resolution authorizing military force against Iraq said they want a Jan. 1 deadline. An administration official pointed out that Secretary of State James A. Baker III has been talking about an end-of-year deadline during his recent globe-trotting campaign to win their support for a U.N. resolution authorizing force. ``We've just kind of formalized that'' in the draft resolution given to other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, said the official on condition of anonymity. Also Sunday, Kuwait's government-in-exile, citing reports from escapees, said Kuwaiti resistance fighters had recently wounded the Iraqi-appointed governor of Kuwait. The report could not be independently confirmed, but Iraq did announce the appointment of a new governor earlier this month, without saying why the former one was being replaced. Iraq continued its piecemeal release of foreign hostages, but no Americans were among those freed Sunday. More than 100 German hostages arrived home after nearly four months of captivity, and 10 Greeks returned to Athens. Iraqi officials also said 70 Italians would be freed Tuesday. Dozens of former government leaders and other dignitaries have traveled to Baghdad to try to win the release of captive foreigners, even though such private trips are discouraged by the U.S. government. The latest such visitor was boxing legend Muhammad Ali, who had planned to meet with Saddam Hussein on Sunday at the presidential palace. The session was postponed and no new date for the meeting was announced. An earlier, erroneous report had said the two met. An Ali associate, Arthur Morrison, said the former world heavyweight champion was on a ``goodwill mission'' and hoped to free some Americans. Morrison spoke to reporters on behalf of Ali, who is suffering from Parkinson's disease and cannot speak. U.S. officials, meanwhile, were laying the groundwork for what they hope will be a U.N. vote by Thursday on the resolution to authorize use of force against Iraq. The United States is seeking a vote this week because its one-month presidency of the 15-member Security Council ends Friday. Taking over is the Red Sea state of Yemen, which has supported Iraq in the past. But Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said Sunday that American forces could move against Iraq without U.N. approval. Bush made a similar statement Friday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III spent last week in an intensive round of lobbying for the measure. Malaysia's foreign minister said after meeting with Baker on Saturday that he believed the meeting would take place Thursday. The Los Angeles Times also said in Sunday editions the vote was expected then. Canadian External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said Sunday his country supports the resolution and called it a ``final attempt'' for a peaceful settlement to the gulf crisis. Canada is a non-permanent member of the council. Iraq, meanwhile, was underscoring its determination to hang onto the emirate even in the face of a military strike. It said if the U.S.-led military force tried to dislodge it from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and other gulf states would be hit by missile attacks. ``The springboards for any aggression targeting Iraq will without exception become a theater of operation if the U.S. administration and its allies insist on the military option,'' the army's al-Qadissiyah daily newspaper declared. The Iraqi threat was seen by some as an effort to drive a wedge between the United States and Saudi Arabia. Some Saudi officials are believed to oppose an offensive from their soil. The U.S.-led force was originally deployed with the stated aim of defending Saudi Arabia against any new Iraqi aggression, but President Bush has said a buildup now underway would give the force offensive capability. About 26 nations have sent 350,000 troops to the gulf region. They include 230,000 American troops, and 200,000 more are on the way. The multinational force faces an estimated 460,000 Iraqi troops stationed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. Iraq indicated it would strengthen its army even at the cost of cutting food production. A government decree published in Baghdad newspapers said farmers, who had formerly been exempted from military service, would now be called to serve. Official Iraqi sources said an estimated 60,000 farmers, most of them military reservists, would be called up in the next few days. The Iraqi News Agency report on rationing in Kuwait said preparations were under way to distribute ration cards to citizens and oreigners. It did not specify what foodstuffs were involved, but bread, sugar, meat and milk are all rationed in Iraq. A spokesman for the Kuwaiti government-in-exile, Abdel-Razzaq Saqer, had few details about the reported attack by resistance fighters on Ali Hassan Majeed, the Iraqi-appointed governor of Kuwait. He cited Kuwaiti exiles as saying the governor had been wounded in the shoulder in the attack by resistance fighters. No date was given for the reported attack. Majeed was appointed as governor after the Iraqi takeover. But earlier this month, without explanation, Saddam named a new governor.

DOC.HEAD: Doo Dah Parade in Pasadena Mocks Self and Institutions
DOC.TEXT: The Doo Dah Parade, an irreverent spoof of the esteemed Tournament of Roses on New Year's Day, lured about 75,000 spectators curbside for 90 minutes of belly laughs on Sunday. Characters representing Zsa Zsa Gabor, Roseanne Barr, Milli Vanilli, Bart Simpson and even Saddam Hussein strutted their stuff - or got roasted - in ``the 15th occasional'' running of the Thanksgiving weekend event. A well-behaved crowd gathered in 72-degree temperatures to witness the mile-long procession, said police Sgt. Kevin Hall. The Doo Dah was the first of three Los Angeles-area parades Sunday. More than 150,000 people cheered as actors Edward James Olmos and Catherine Bach led off the 16th Annual East Los Angeles Christmas Parade. About 750,000 people lined the streets at 6 p.m. to view the start of the Hollywood Christmas Parade, featuring Arnold Schwarzenegger as grand marshal. ``I'm so excited, I tell you it's absolutely wonderful,'' Schwarzenegger said when the parade began. ``I'm full of energy, ready to go to pump up the Christmas spirit.'' The muscleman sat atop a float bedecked with child co-stars from his new movie, ``Kindergarten Cop.'' Unlike the stately Rose Parade, the Doo Dah Parade has no theme, no prize, and no judge. But like the parade it lampoons, it had a queen. This year's monarch was waitress Lila Johnson, who was crowned after winning an arm wrestling contest. The pop music duo Milli Vanilli was lampooned by many entrants, including the Do It Yourself Milli Vanilli Band lip-syncing ``Girl, You Know It's True.'' Last week, the pair returned their best new artist Grammy Award after it was revealed they never sang a note on their hit record. Roseanne Barr also was targeted. The world's largest shopping cart was pushed down the street on a mission to fill the rotund comedian's grocery list. Boos greeted the Roseanne Barr National Anthem Drill team, which screeched out the actress' infamous rendition of the ``Star-Spangled Banner'' while a group in San Diego Padres uniforms plugged their ears. Television was made fun of, too, as the group Thursday Night Fight put Bart Simpson and Bill Cosby lookalikes in a boxing ring. The Thursday evening shows have been battling it out in a ratings war. Old favorites also were on hand. The synchronized briefcase drill team frowned, businesslike, through their maneuvers; the mobile volleyball team kept the ball in the air as the net moved down the street; and the marching hibachi grill team flung tortillas to the crowd. The real bankers, attorneys and investment advisors in the briefcase team were themselves spoofed by the Bozo Synchronized Briefcase Drill Team in clown makeup and pinstriped suits. The Slap My Face and Call Me Saddam Drill Team offered a solution for the world's most pressing problem. Under a banner reading, ``Zsa Zsa - America's Secret Weapon,'' a group of Zsa Zsas slapped Saddam Hussein posers and wrested globes from the mock strongmen. Some themes were directed at a Californian audience. Architects wearing houses fell prey to imaginary earthquakes, mudslides and brush fires. Medflies danced around marching fruit, flowers and helicopters. They sang about the pesticide Malathion, which state agricultural officials sprayed over Southern California neighborhoods this year in the latest war against the Mediterranean fruit fly.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Continue Pursuing Leads in Murder Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to CLARIFY that authorities have not charged a suspect in case; INSERT background on suspect earlier identified. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The first ...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities investigating the slayings of five college students have not charged a suspect three months later, despite one of the most intense murder probes in Florida history. But while some outside law enforcement officials don't hold out much hope, investigators remain optimistic they will ultimately track down the killer. Authorities have spent $2.5 million to send 75 investigators out to follow some 5,500 leads since the killings in late August. ``This isn't television,'' said Win Phillips, second-in-command at the Alachua County Sheriff's Office. ``It's been time-consuming, labor-intensive and costly.'' Last month, Edward Humphrey, earlier identified as a suspect in the case, was sentenced to 22 months in a prison mental institution for beating his grandmother. The 19-year-old student was never charged in the slayings. The first two victims were found stabbed and mutilated Aug. 26. Sonja Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach, and Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville, were both University of Florida students. Christa Hoyt, 17, a student at nearby Santa Fe Community College, was found the next day, beheaded. University of Florida students Tracy Paules and Manuel Taboada, both 23 of Miami, were found the day after that, stabbed to death. Since then, a task force of investigators from the FBI, Gainesville police, Alachua County Sheriff's Office, Florida Department of Law Enforcement and Florida Highway Patrol have said little about their progress. ``I feel confident we're going to ultimately resolve this thing because of the quantity and quality of the resources working on this,'' said State Attorney Len Register. ``The legends of the FDLE are up here working on this case.'' But outsiders are not convinced an arrest is imminent, or even likely. Michael West, a Mississippi forensic expert, scoured the murder scenes with special laser equipment, looking for fingerprints, footprints, blood or fibers police may have missed. He said he had never seen a crime scene so clean in 13 years of such work. ``This person didn't leave them anything to work with,'' West said. ``He didn't wake up one morning and decide to kill. He did some planning and was careful.'' ``They're in a hell of a bind,'' said Leon County Sheriff's Capt. Steve Bodiford, who helped investigate the Ted Bundy serial murder case in the late 1970s. Bundy confessed to killing 23 young women. ``What do you do? If you have no evidence, you run all the leads down and try to develop new leads. It's tough,'' Bodiford said. Leon County incorporates Tallahassee in northwest Florida. So many leads are being pursued that the task force has discouraged victims' families and the university from offering rewards - a traditional way of generating leads. ``They're afraid of leaks, so they're not telling us anything,'' said Ada Larson, mother of one of the victims. ``Recently, they don't return my calls.'' Mario Taboada, whose brother was killed, said he would let the investigation take its course. ``I've been very patient, because I know every little item picked up needs to be written up, documented, processed,'' he said. ``Obviously that's time-consuming.'' Meanwhile, university officials worry that students have grown complacent. Campus police spokesman Angie Tipton said students have since dropped their guard, walking alone at night, leaving doors and windows unlocked. ``It's like nothing ever happened,'' Ms. Tipton said. ``We try to remind them that the victims were just like they are: vulnerable and trusting.''

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Marcos Wants to Give Money From Frozen Account to Typhoon Victims
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos has offered to give about $3.6 million in bank account funds frozen in the Philippines to the victims of a typhoon that killed 300 people in her homeland. Mrs. Marcos made her offer of 100 Philippine pesos, or about $3.6 million, on Friday, attorney James P. Linn said in a telephone interview Sunday from his home in Oklahoma City. She had not yet received a response from the Philippine government, which would have to approve the release of the funds, Linn said. Typhoon Mike devastated the city of Cebu in mid-November. An earlier offer by Mrs. Marcos to give an identical amount in Swiss bank account funds to the victims of a July earthquake that killed an estimated 1,600 Filipinos was rejected by the ruling Aquino government, Linn said. There were ``no strings attached,'' Linn said. ``She's very much a Filipino woman and very much concerned about her country,'' Linn said. ``This is her idea. She'd do a good deal more than that if they'd let her.'' The Philippine government has a $5 billion racketeering lawsuit pending against Mrs. Marcos and the estate of her late husband, Ferdinand, the former Philippine president. The lawsuit alleges the couple and their cronies looted the Philippine treasury during Marcos' 20-year rule. He was deposed in 1986 and died in exile in Hawaii last year. The Philippine government has said it would settle the racketeering lawsuit if it gets at least 60 percent of the money in a half-dozen Marcos bank accounts in Hong Kong. The 60 percent is believed to be worth about $250 million. A hearing on the proposed settlement is scheduled Dec. 10 in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted of criminal racketeering in July.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dressed As Christmas Elf Injured During Parachute Jump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs to UPDATE with man hospitalized overnight; children sending him cards. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A parachutist dressed as a Christmas elf lost control and landed on a moving car in front of thousands of spectators at a Christmas festival. Robert G. Humphrey of Holbrook was hospitalized after he was carried by a wind squall from his intended target, Faxon Field, and landed on a moving car nearby Saturday. More than 1,000 spectators were gathered to watch the annual Christmas parachute jump, sponsored by the Quincy Christmas Festival Committee. Police said Humphrey was falling at about 30 mph when he hit the car and bounced into the street. Humphrey, 39, was to spend Sunday night at Quincy Hospital, where he was being treated for a broken knee, a broken leg and bruises. Humphrey said in a telephone interview that children already were sending him get-well cards. Parachutists dressed as Santa Claus and other elves landed safely.
